revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10ehf1) ([[User:Josve05a|Josve05a]])
revision.text:
{{update|date=November 2014}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Good article}} The multinational technology corporation '''[[Apple Inc.]]''' has been a participant in various legal proceedings and claims since it began operation and, like its competitors and peers, engages in [[litigation]] in its normal course of business for a variety of reasons. In particular, Apple is known for and promotes itself as actively and aggressively enforcing its [[intellectual property]] interests.<ref name="genPatent">[http://www.generalpatent.com/remembering-steve-jobs Remembering Steve Jobs], General Patent Corporation, generalpatent.com, 2012-2. Accessed April 13, 2012. * Worthington, David, [http://www.pcworld.com/article/190799/apples_lawsuit_against_htc_bad_for_consumers.html Apple's Lawsuit Against HTC: Bad for Consumers?], PCWorld, pcworld.com, March 4, 2010. Accessed 2012-4-13. * [https://www.apple.com/legal/trademark/piracy.html Apple Legal – Piracy Prevention], Apple, Inc., apple.com. Accessed 2012-7-22.</ref><ref name="mosesLeeNoI">Moses, Lee, and Asher, Julian, [http://www.smh.com.au/digital-life/mp3s/apples-future-wont-be-brought-to-you-by-the-letter-i-20100312-q27r.html Apple's future won't be brought to you by the letter 'i'], ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'' (SMH), smh.com.au, March 12, 2010. Accessed 2012-4-13.</ref> From the 1980s to the present, Apple has been plaintiff or defendant in [[Lawsuit|civil action]]s in the [[United States]] and other countries. Some of these actions have determined significant [[case law]] for the [[information technology]] industry and many have captured the attention of the public and media. Apple's litigation generally involves intellectual property disputes, but the company has also been a party in lawsuits that include [[competition law|antitrust]] claims, consumer actions, commercial [[unfair competition|unfair trade practice]] suits, [[defamation]] claims, and [[industrial espionage|corporate espionage]], among other matters. {{TOC limit|3}}
==Background== Apple is a member of the [[Business Software Alliance]] (BSA), whose principal activity is trying to stop copyright infringement of software produced by BSA members; Apple treats all its intellectual property as a business asset, engaging in litigation as one method among many to police its assets and to respond to claims by others against it.<ref name="applTmPirPol">[https://www.apple.com/legal/trademark/piracy.html Apple Trademarks – Piracy Policy], Apple, Inc., apple.com. Accessed April 12, 2012.</ref> Apple's portfolio of intellectual property is broad enough, for [[trademark]]s alone, to encompass several pages of the company's web site and, in April 2012, it listed 176 general business trademarks, 79 [[service mark]]s, 7 trademarks related to [[NeXT]] products and services, and 2 trademarks related to [[FileMaker]].<ref>[https://www.apple.com/legal/trademark/appletmlist.html Apple trademark list], and [https://www.apple.com/legal/trademark/nexttmlist.html NeXT trademark list], Apple, Inc., apple.com. [http://www.filemaker.com/company/legal/trademark_guidelines.html Filemaker trademark list], FileMaker, Inc., filemaker.com. Accessed April 12, 2012.</ref> Apple claims [[copyright]] interests in multiple products and processes and owns and licenses [[patent]]s of various types as well and, while it states it generally does not license its patent portfolio, it does work with third parties having an interest in product interoperability.<ref>[https://www.apple.com/legal/contact/patent.html Apple Legal – Patents], Apple, Inc., apple.com. Accessed April 12, 2012.</ref> [[Steve Jobs]] alone was a named inventor on over 300 design and utility patents.<ref name="genPatent" /><ref>Helft, Miguel, and Carter, Shan, [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/26/technology/apple-patents-show-steve-jobss-attention-to-design.html?_r=1 Apple Patents Show Steve Jobs's Attention to Design], ''[[The New York Times]]'', nytimes.com, August 25, 2011. Accessed 2012-4-13.</ref> Between January 2008 and May 2010, Apple Inc. filed more than 350 cases with the [[United States Patent and Trademark Office|U.S. Patent and Trademark office]] (USPTO) alone, most in opposition to or taking exception to others' use of the terms "apple", "pod", and "safari"; those cases include sellers of apples (the fruit), as well as many others' less unassuming use of the term "apple".<ref name="appleTTAB">U.S. Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO), [http://ttabvue.uspto.gov/ttabvue/v?pnam=Apple%20Inc.%20%20&page=15 U.S. Trademark Trial and Appeal Board search for 'Apple Inc.'.] Accessed July 26, 2012. (This search is not instant and takes a minute to return results.)</ref>
==Antitrust==
===Apple iPod, iTunes antitrust litigation=== The case ''In re Apple iPod iTunes Antitrust Litigation'' was filed as a [[class action]] in 2005<ref name="MacLean">MacLean, Pamela, and Gullo, Karen, [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-22/apple-s-jobs-must-answer-questions-in-itunes-antitrust-dispute.html Apple's Jobs Must Answer Questions in ITunes Antitrust Suit], Bloomberg News, bloomberg.com, March 22, 2011. Accessed 2012-4-13. Apple customer Thomas Slattery filed the suit seeking class-action status on behalf of consumers, claiming Apple illegally limited consumer choice by limiting iPod content selection to the company's own iTunes music store.</ref> claiming Apple violated the U.S. antitrust statutes in operating a music-downloading [[monopoly]] that it created by changing its software design to the proprietary [[FairPlay]] [[Code|encoding]] in 2004, resulting in other vendors' music files being incompatible with and thus inoperable on the [[iPod]].<ref>''[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=17764978882748288683 In re Apple iPod iTunes Antitrust Litigation]'', case C-05-00037-JW, 2008 U.S. Dist. [[LexisNexis|LEXIS]] 107127, N.D. Cal., December 22, 2008. Accessed 2012-7-26.</ref> The suit initially alleged that five days after [[RealNetworks]] released in 2004 its [[FairPlay#Harmony: RealPlayer Music on the iPod|Harmony]] technology making its music playable on iPods, Apple changed its software such that the RealNetworks music would no longer play on iPods.<ref>Sharpe, N.F., and Arewa, O.B., [http://scholarlycommons.law.northwestern.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1144&context=njtip Is Apple Playing Fair? Navigating the iPod FairPlay DRM Controversy], ''NW Jour. of Tech. & Intell. Prop.'', 5:2, 2007, p. 332. Accessed July 22, 2012.</ref> The claims of Apple's changes to its encoding and its refusal to license FairPlay technology to other companies were dismissed by the court 2009, but the allegation of Apple's monopoly on the iPod's music download capabilities between 2004 and 2009 remained as of July 2012.<ref>Cheng, Jacqui, [https://arstechnica.com/apple/2012/05/ipod-owners-being-notified-of-class-action-antitrust-suit-against-apple/ iPod owners being notified of class-action antitrust suit against Apple], The lawsuit has been winding its way through the legal system since 2004, [[Ars Technica]], arstechnica.com, May 9, 2012. Accessed July 23, 2012. The case was granted class action status in 2012 and a website was set up for class members: [https://ipodlawsuit.com/ ipodlawsuit.com] (this link works only with [[HTTP referer|referrer]]s turned on in the browser).</ref> In March 2011, [[Bloomberg L.P.|''Bloomberg'']] reported that, after a related 3-year inquiry by the [[Competition Commission (United Kingdom)|Competition Commission]], Apple agreed in 2008 to lower its prices on [[iTunes]] tracks sold in the United Kingdom and that Steve Jobs had been directed by the court in March 2011 to make himself available to be [[Deposition (law)|deposed]] on Apple's FairPlay changes as they relate to the plaintiffs' monopolization claim.<ref name="MacLean"/>
===Apple and AT&T Mobility antitrust class action=== In October 2007 (four months after the [[iPhone]] was introduced), Paul Holman and Lucy Rivello filed a class action lawsuit (numbered C07-05152) in the Northern District of California. The lawsuit referenced Apple's [[SIM lock]] on the iPhone and Apple's (at the time) complete ban on third-party apps, and alleged that the 1.1.1 software update was "expressly designed" to disable unapproved SIM cards and apps. The lawsuit said that this was an unfair, unlawful, and fraudulent business practice (see [[False advertising]]) under California's Unfair Competition Law; that the combination of [[AT&T Mobility|AT&T Mobility]] and Apple was to reduce competition and cause a monopoly in violation of California's antitrust law and the [[Sherman Antitrust Act]]; and that this disabling was a violation of the [[Protected computer|Consumer Fraud and Abuse Act]].<ref>"[http://docs.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/california/candce/5:2007cv05152/196514/1/0.pdf?ts=1377199493]" Complaint, Paul Holman et al. v. Apple Inc. et al. No. 07-05152, U.S. Dist.Ct., N.D. Cal. 2007. Accessed August 25, 2013.</ref>
Shortly after this initial filing, other lawsuits were filed, and these were consolidated with the original Holman suit, bringing in additional plaintiffs and complaints: Timothy Smith, et al., v. Apple, Inc. et al., No. C 07-05662 RMW, adding complaints related to ringtones,<ref>[http://docs.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/california/candce/5:2007cv05152/196514/34/0.pdf?ts=1376380861] Order Relating Cases; Consolidating Cases; And Setting Case Management Conference, In Re Apple & AT&TM Anti-Trust Litigation No. C 07-05152 & No. C 07-05662, U.S. Dist.Ct., N.D. Cal. 2008. Accessed August 25, 2013.</ref> and Kliegerman v. Apple, Inc., No. C 08-948, bringing in allegations under the federal [[Magnuson–Moss Warranty Act]].<ref>[http://docs.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/california/candce/5:2007cv05152/196514/86/0.pdf?ts=1376380861] Stipulation And Order Granting Plaintiff's Administrative Motion To Relate Cases Under L.R. 3-12, In Re Apple & AT&TM Anti-Trust Litigation No. C 07-05152, U.S. Dist.Ct., N.D. Cal. 2008. Accessed August 25, 2013.</ref> The combined case title was changed to "In Re Apple & AT&TM Anti-Trust Litigation." The court appointed lead counsel from the various plaintiffs' lawyers, and several versions of a combined complaint were filed.
In October 2008, the court denied the defendants' motions to dismiss the case on the federal claims and granted their motions to dismiss the state unfair trade practice claims except in California, New York, and Washington, but gave the plaintiffs leave to amend those claims.<ref>In re Apple & AT & T M Antitrust Litig., No. C 07-05152 JW, 2010 WL 3521965, N.D. Cal., 2010-7-8, pp. 5–8. Accessed July 25, 2012.</ref> In December 2011, the district court granted Apple and AT&T's motions to compel arbitration, following the Supreme Court decision in ''[[AT&T Mobility v. Concepcion]]'', and decertified the class; in April 2012 the Ninth Circuit denied plaintiffs permission to appeal.<ref name="ATTM0816Dismissal">[https://www.wsj.com/public/resources/documents/0816AppleSuit.pdf] Order Granting Apple's Motion To Dismiss Amended Consolidated Complaint, In Re Apple iPhone Antitrust Litigation No. C 11-cv-06714-YGR, U.S. Dist.Ct., N.D. Cal. 2013. Accessed August 25, 2013.</ref>
In December 2011, immediately after class decertification of the previous case, a new group of plaintiffs led by Robert Pepper won the race to the courthouse by filing a complaint in the Northern District, which was combined with some slightly later filers and titled "In re Apple iPhone Antitrust Litigation", case 11-cv-06714-YGR. The new case is essentially the same but is filed only against Apple, not AT&T Mobility. In late 2013, the various parts of the case were dismissed by the district court. The parts relating to SIM locking were rejected because AT&T was not a party and the plaintiffs were not willing to add AT&T.<ref name="ATTM0816Dismissal"/> The remaining claim, in its final version, was that Apple monopolised the market for iPhone applications and that the plaintiffs were damaged by paying Apple's 30% commission for paid applications in the App Store, which the court rejected saying that the commission was "a cost passed-on to consumers by independent software developers", not paid by the consumers directly, and so the plaintiffs did not have standing under the [[Illinois Brick Co v. Illinois|Illinois Brick]] doctrine.<ref>[http://docs.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/california/candce/4:2011cv06714/249697/124/0.pdf?1386062572] Order Granting Apple's Motion To Dismiss Second Amended Complaint With Prejudice, In Re Apple iPhone Anti-Trust Litigation No. C 11-cv-06714-YGR, U.S. Dist.Ct., N.D. Cal. 2013. Accessed December 18, 2013.</ref>
The plaintiffs appealed to the Ninth District, which reversed the District Court's dismissal. The Ninth Circuit asked the question that in light of Illinois Brick, if Apple was to be treated as a manufacturer or producer, in which case the class did not have standing to sue, or if they were a distributor, in which case the class could sue for damages.<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.zdnet.com/article/us-appeals-court-reopens-lawsuit-against-apple-for-alleged-app-store-monopoly/ |title= US appeals court reopens lawsuit against Apple for alleged App Store monopoly |first= Stephanie |last= Condon |date= January 12, 2017 |accessdate= June 18, 2018 |work = [[ZDNet]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/us-otc-apple/9th-circuit-apple-antitrust-ruling-splits-with-8th-is-boon-to-consumers-idUSKBN14X2HV |title= 9th Circuit Apple antitrust ruling splits with 8th, is boon to consumers |first= Alison |last= Frankel |date= January 13, 2017 |accessdate= June 18, 2018 |publisher= [[Reuters]] }}</ref>
Apple appealed the case to the [[Supreme Court of the United States]], which agreed to hear the case, ''[[Apple Inc. v. Pepper]]'' in its 2018 term.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-06-18/apple-gets-u-s-supreme-court-review-on-iphone-app-fee-suit | title = Apple Gets U.S. Supreme Court Review on iPhone App Fee Suit | first = Greg | last = Stohr | date = June 18, 2018 | accessdate = June 18, 2018 | work = [[Bloomberg L.P.]] }}</ref>
===European antitrust investigation=== In 2008, Apple agreed to cut the price UK consumers pay to download music for their iPods after a formal complaint to the [[European Commission]] from the UK consumer group ''[[Which?]]'' demonstrated higher prices in UK for the same iTunes songs sold elsewhere in the [[European Union]] (EU).<ref>Apple, Inc., [https://www.apple.com/pr/library/2008/01/09Apple-to-Standardize-iTunes-Music-Prices-Throughout-Europe.html Apple to Standardize iTunes Music Prices Throughout Europe], apple.com, January 9, 2008. Accessed April 2, 2012.</ref> The Commission began an antitrust investigation in 2007 of Apple's business practices after the complaint was made,<ref name="nottheapple">[http://www.spiegel.de/international/business/not-the-apple-of-the-eu-s-eye-brussels-accuses-itunes-of-violating-competition-rules-a-475398.html Not the Apple of the EU's Eye: Brussels Accuses iTunes of Violating Competition Rules], ''[[Spiegel Online]]'' International, April 3, 2007. Accessed July 22, 2012.</ref> but ultimately the Commission probe found no agreements between Apple and major record labels on how iTunes is run in Europe,<ref name="oatesTunesUK">Oates, John, [https://www.theregister.co.uk/2008/01/09/apple_cuts_uk_prices/ Apple cuts UK iTunes prices, Heads off EC investigation], ''[[The Register]]'', January 9, 2008. Accessed April 1, 2012.</ref> only that Apple had been paying higher wholesale prices to UK music labels and was passing the cost along to UK customers.<ref name="oatesTunesUK" /><ref>European Commission, [http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=IP/08/22&format=HTML&aged=0&language=EN&guiLanguage=en Antitrust: European Commission welcomes Apple's announcement to equalise prices for music downloads from iTunes in Europe], europa.eu, January 9, 2008. Accessed April 1, 2012.</ref>
===eBook price-fixing lawsuit=== {{main|United States v. Apple Inc.}} In April 2012, the [[United States Department of Justice|U.S. Justice Department]] (DOJ) and 33 U.S. states brought a civil antitrust action against Apple, [[HarperCollins]], [[Macmillan Publishers]], [[Penguin Books]], [[Simon & Schuster]], and [[Hachette Book Group USA|Hachette Book Group, Inc.]], alleging violations of the Sherman Act.<ref>Sherman Antitrust Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=US court rules Apple conspired with five publishers to fix e-book prices|author=Jamie Dunkley|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/us-court-rules-apple-conspired-with-five-publishers-to-fix-ebook-prices-8700878.html|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=July 11, 2013 |accessdate=July 11, 2013 |location=London}}</ref><ref name="eBkSuit">Complaint, ''[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/shared/bsp/hi/pdfs/11_04_11_applecomplaint.pdf U.S. v. Apple, Inc.], Hachette Book Group, Inc., Harpercollins Publishers LLC, Verlagsgruppe Georg Von Holtzbrinck GMBH, Holtzbrinck Publishers, LLC d/b/a Macmillan, The Penguin Group, a Division of Pearson PLC, Penguin Group (USA), Inc., and Simon & Schuster, Inc.'', case 1:12-cv-02826-UA and 11-md-02293, U.S. Dist. Ct., S.D.N.Y., filed April 11, 2012. Accessed 2012-4-12.</ref> The suit was filed in the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of New York|Southern District of New York]] and alleges the defendants conspired to restrain retail price competition in the sale of [[e-book]]s because they viewed [[Amazon.com|Amazon]]'s price discounting as a substantial challenge to their traditional business model.<ref name="eBkSuit"/><ref>[[NPR]], [https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2012/04/11/150418670/justice-dept-accuses-apple-and-others-of-fixing-e-book-prices Justice Dept. Accuses Apple And Others Of Fixing E-Book Prices], ''The Two–Way'', npr.org, April 12, 2012. Accessed 2012-4-12.</ref> Regarding Apple in particular, the federal complaint alleged that "Apple facilitated the Publisher Defendants' collective effort to end retail price competition by coordinating their transition to an agency model across all retailers. Apple clearly understood that its participation in this scheme would result in higher prices to consumers."<ref>''U.S. v. Apple, et al.'', Complaint, p.4.</ref> In such an agency-model, publishers set prices rather than sellers.<ref name="bbcUSvApple">[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-17681137 US sues Apple and publishers over e-book prices], [[BBC]] News, bbc.co.uk, April 11, 2012. Accessed 2012-4-12.</ref><ref name="bbcQAebk">[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-17685120 Q&A: Apple and e-book prices], BBC News, bbc.co.uk, April 11, 2012. Accessed 2012-4-12.</ref> Fifteen states and Puerto Rico also filed a companion federal case in Austin, Texas, against Apple, Penguin, Simon & Schuster and Macmillan.<ref>Forden, Sara, and Bliss, Jeff, [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-04-11/u-s-sues-apple-for-ebook-pricing-as-three-firms-settle.html U.S. Sues Apple For eBook Pricing as Three Firms Settle], Bloomberg News, bloomberg.com, April 11, 2012. Accessed 2012-4-13.</ref> In the same month, HarperCollins, Hachette and Simon & Schuster settled with both the DOJ and the state attorneys general, with HarperCollins and Hachette agreeing to pay Texas and Connecticut $52 million in consumer restitution, leaving Apple, Penguin, and Macmillan as remaining defendants.<ref>Parnell, Brid-Aine, [https://www.theregister.co.uk/2012/04/12/us_states_ebook_suit_for_cash/ Publishers fork out ,2m in Apple ebook pricing settlement], The Register, theregister.co.uk, April 12, 2012. Accessed 2012-4-18.</ref> As of July 2012, the case was still in the [[Discovery (law)|discovery]] stage of litigation.<ref>Van Voris, Bob, [http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-07-20/steve-jobs-interviews-sought-by-plaintiffs-in-e-book-suit Steve Jobs Interviews Sought by Plaintiffs in E-Book Suit], Bloomberg Businessweek, businessweek.com, July 20, 2012. Accessed 2012-7-26.</ref> On July 10, 2013, District Court Judge Denise Cote in Manhattan found Apple Inc. guilty of the violation of federal antitrust law, citing "compelling evidence" that Apple played a "central role" in a conspiracy with publishers to eliminate retail competition and the prices of e-books.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/07/10/us-apple-ebooks-idUSBRE9690GE20130710 | work=Reuters | title=Apple colluded on e-book prices, judge finds | date=July 10, 2013}}</ref>
=== High-Tech Employee Antitrust Litigation === {{main|High-Tech Employee Antitrust Litigation}}
In 2014, Apple settled out of court both an antitrust lawsuit and a related class-action suit regarding [[cold calling]] employees of other companies. <ref>Levine, Dan, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/apple-google-agree-to-settle-lawsuit-alleging-hiring-salary-conspiracy/2014/04/24/56f1bb32-cbff-11e3-95f7-7ecdde72d2ea_story.html?tid=hpModule_a2e19bf4-86a3-11e2-9d71-f0feafdd1394 Apple, Google agree to settle lawsuit alleging hiring, salary conspiracy], ''[[The Washington Post]]'', April 24, 2014. Accessed 2015-07-04.</ref>
==Consumer class actions==
===Technical support class action=== From 1993 to 1996, Apple developed a marketing strategy that promised free and unlimited live-telephone support on certain products for as long as the original purchaser owned those products; by 1997, however, changes in Apple's [[AppleCare]] support policy led Apple to rescind the offer, resulting in a consumer class action lawsuit for breach of contract.<ref>''[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=12455738165873813328 Wershba v. Apple Computer, Inc.]'', 110 Cal. Rptr. 2d 145, Cal. Ct. App., 6th App. Dist 2001. Accessed April 2, 2012.</ref> Apple denied wrongdoing but, in settlement of the claims, Apple ultimately reinstated the telephone support for the duration of original ownership of the otherwise obsolete products and customers affected by the change were given a limited reimbursement if they had been refused telephone support, had been charged per incident, or had incurred third party support charges.<ref>Apple, Inc., [http://www.info.apple.com/usen/legacy/legacyfaq.html Support for Legacy Products FAQ (Frequently Asked Questions)], apple.com, April 1, 2012. Accessed April 2, 2012. The deadline to submit claims on the unlimited live-telephone support matter was September 8, 1999.</ref>
===iPod battery life class action=== In 2004 and 2005, two state-level class action suits were filed against Apple in New York and California alleging the first, second, and third generation [[iPod]] music players sold prior to May 2004 did not have the battery life represented and/or that the battery's capacity to take and hold a charge substantially diminished over time.<ref>[http://bankrupt.com/CAR_Public/040816.mbx Class Action Reporter], bankrupt.com (Beard Group), Vol. 6, No. 161, August 16, 2004. Accessed April 1, 2012.</ref><ref name="TenQ2004">Apple Computer Inc., [https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/320193/000110465905003520/a05-2329_110q.htm SEC Form 10-Q], February 1, 2005. Accessed April 2, 2012.</ref><ref name="appleipodsettlement">California case: ''[http://www.wlf.org/Upload/litigation/briefs/IPOD.pdf In re iPod Cases] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111132552/http://www.wlf.org/Upload/litigation/briefs/IPOD.pdf |date=November 11, 2013 }}'', Judicial Council Coordination Proceeding No. 4355, San Mateo Co. Sup. Ct.; and New York action: ''Mosley v. Apple Computer, Inc.'', case 7-04-cv-5773, U.S. Dist. Ct., S.D.N.Y. (the "Mosley Action"). The information site Apple created for the California class action posted the {{cite web |url=http://www.appleipodsettlement.com/notice.html |title=Notice of Pendency and Proposed Settlement of Class Action |accessdate=2017-02-27 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070705114128/http://www.appleipodsettlement.com/notice.html |archivedate=July 5, 2007 |df= }}.</ref> Rather than litigate these claims, Apple entered into a settlement agreement in August 2005 after a fairness hearing in the California action, with the settlement terms designed to end the New York action as well. An appeal followed the California court's approval of the settlement but the appellate court upheld the settlement in December 2005.<ref>[http://bankrupt.com/CAR_Public/060213.mbx Class Action Reporter], bankrupt.com (Beard Group), 8:31, February 13, 2006. Accessed April 2, 2012.</ref><ref name="app10q06">Apple Computer, Inc., [https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/320193/000110465906005910/a06-3798_110q.htm SEC Form 10-Q], February 3, 2006. Accessed April 2, 2012.</ref> Eligible members of the class were entitled to extended warranties, store credit, cash compensation, or battery replacement, and some incentive payments, with all unfiled claims expiring after September 2005. Apple agreed to pay all costs of the litigation, including incentive payments to the class members and the plaintiffs' attorney fees, but admitted no fault.<ref name="appleipodsettlement" /><ref name="app10q06" /> In 2006 Apple Canada, Inc., also settled several similar Canadian class action suits alleging misrepresentations by Apple regarding iPod battery life.<ref name="app10q08">Apple, Inc., [https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/320193/000119312508097759/d10q.htm SEC Form 10-Q], May 1, 2008. Accessed April 2, 2012. The Canadian suits were termed ''Lenzi v. Apple Canada, Inc.''; ''Wolfe v. Apple Computer, Inc. and Apple Canada, Inc.''; ''Hirst v. Apple Canada, Inc.''; ''Hamilton v. Apple Computer, Inc. and Apple Canada, Inc.''.</ref>
===iPad and iPhone privacy issue class action=== In December 2010, two separate groups of iPhone and [[iPad]] users sued Apple, alleging that certain software applications were passing personal user information to third-party advertisers without the users' consent.<ref name="Thomson Reuters">Mukherjee and Ahmed, [https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/12/28/us-apple-lawsuit-idUSTRE6BR1Y820101228 Apple sued over apps privacy issues; Google may be next], [[Reuters]], December 28, 2010. Accessed 2012-7-23.</ref> The individual cases were consolidated in the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California]], San Jose division, under the title ''In Re iPhone Application Litigaton'', and further defendants were added to the action.<ref name="inReIphone">''[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=14821999513909093166 In Re iPhone Application Litigation]'', case 10-CV-05878-LHK, U.S. Dist.Ct., N.D. Cal. 2011. Accessed January 28, 2012. Other consolidated actions related to the matter were identified by the court as: ''Chiu v. Apple, Inc.'', 11-cv-00407-LHK, filed 2011-1-27; ''Rodimer v. Apple, Inc., et al.'', 11-cv-00700-LHK, filed 2011-2-15; ''Gupta v. Apple, Inc.'', 11-cv-02110-LHK, filed 2011-4-28; ''Velez-Colon v. Apple, Inc.'', 11-cv-02270-LHK, filed May 9, 2011; ''Normand v. Apple, Inc.'', 11-cv-02317-LHK, filed 2011-5-10; and one case not yet consolidated, ''Jenkins v. Apple, Inc.'', 11-cv-01828-LHK, removed 2011-4-14. Other related actions with substantially similar allegations against Apple and other Defendants were filed in the [[United States District Court for the District of Puerto Rico|District of Puerto Rico]] and the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama|Northern District of Alabama]].</ref> The complainants petitioned the court for a ban on the "passing of user information without consent and monetary compensation,"<ref name="Thomson Reuters"/> claimed damages for breach of privacy, and sought redress for other enumerated claims.<ref name="kohStandingOrder">[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=11552215207215157219 Order Granting Defendants' Motions To Dismiss For Lack Of Article III Standing With Leave To Amend], ''In Re iPhone Application Litigation'', case 11-MD-02250-LHK, September 20, 2011. The Consolidated Complaint contains eight claims: (1) [[Negligence]] against Apple only; (2) Violation of [[Computer Fraud and Abuse Act]] ("CFAA"), 18 U.S.C. § 1030; (3) Computer Crime Law, Cal. Penal Code § 502; (4) Trespass on [[Personal property|Chattel]]; (5) Consumer Legal Remedies Act ("CLRA"), Cal. Civ. Code § 1750 against Apple only; (6) Unfair Competition under Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code § 17200; (7) Breach of Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing; and (8) Unjust Enrichment.</ref> Press reports stated that in April 2011, Apple agreed to amend its developer agreement to stop this from happening "except for information directly necessary for the functionality of the apps"; however, the suit alleged that Apple took no steps to do this or enforce it "in any meaningful way due to criticism from advertising networks".<ref name="Thomson Reuters" />
The [[Associated Press]] reported a pending congressional inquiry into the matter, with [[United States Congress]] members stating that commercial storage and usage of location information without a consumer's express consent is illegal under current law, but Apple defended its use of customer tracking in a letter released May 9, 2011, by the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]].<ref name="CongressInquiry">Robertson, Jordan, [http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/apr/21/apple-slammed-over-iphone-ipad-location-tracking/ Apple Slammed Over iPhone, iPad Location Tracking], ''[[The Washington Times]]'', washingtontimes.com, July 22, 2012.</ref><ref name="Logging">AP, [http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/42981590/ns/technology_and_science-wireless/t/apple-defends-iphone-hot-spot-logging/ Apple Defends IPhone 'Hot Spot'-Logging], [[MSNBC]], msnbc.msn.com, May 10, 2011.</ref> [[NPR|National Public Radio]]'s senior director of technology published an article examining the data collected by his own iPhone, showing examples of the data collected and maps correlating the data.<ref name="Brand-NPR">Brand, Zach, [https://www.npr.org/blogs/alltechconsidered/2011/04/24/135639390/sifting-through-an-iphones-data-row-by-row Sifting Through An iPhone's Geo Data, Row By Row], National Public Radio, ''All Tech Considered'', npr.org, April 23, 2011.</ref> Separately, digital forensics researchers reported they regularly use the data collected from Apple mobile devices in working with law enforcement officials investigating crimes and have been doing so since at least mid-2010.<ref name="Wolverton">Wolverton, Troy, [http://www.mercurynews.com/top-stories/ci_17903104 Investigators use iPhones to track owners' movements], ''[[San Jose Mercury News]]'', April 21, 2011.</ref> In contrast with earlier statements, Apple revealed in a hearing with the [[U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee]] that a "software bug" caused iPhones to continue to send anonymous location data to the company's servers, even when location services on the device were turned off.<ref name="Tessler">Tessler, Joelle, AP, [http://www.mercurynews.com/business/ci_18138774 Sen. Al Franken calls for Apple, Google app privacy policies], ''San Jose Mercury News'', May 25, 2011.</ref>
In September 2011, the District Court granted Apple's [[Motion (legal)#Motion to dismiss|motion to dismiss]] for lack of [[Article Three of the United States Constitution|Article III]] [[Standing (law)|standing]] and [[Motion (legal)#Motion for summary judgment|failure to state a claim]], but gave the plaintiffs leave to amend their complaint, thereby not shutting out the claims permanently.<ref name="kohStandingOrder"/> The court ruled that without a showing of [[Damages|legal damages]] compensable under current law, the plaintiffs had not shown they sustained injury in fact by the defendants' actions. The problem facing the plaintiffs is the current state of electronic [[privacy law]], the issue being that there is no national privacy law that provides for compensatory damages for breach of privacy, and this is the same issue faced by victims of [[data breach]]es, as breaches, per se, sustain no legal damages without a showing of actual and measurable harm such as monetary loss.<ref>Romanosky, Sasha, Hoffman, David, and Acquisti, Alessandro, [http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1986461 Empirical Analysis of Data Breach Litigation], Heinz Col. of Pub. Pol. and Info. Systems, Carnegie Mellon Univ., Beasley School of Law, Temple Univ., February 19, 2012. Accessed 2012-7-23.</ref> Under U.S. law as of July 2012, it is only when a data breach results in actual loss as defined by applicable law that compensable damages arise.<ref name="Ceridian">A case illustrating the 'no damages' problem is the ''Ceridian'' case: the Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit affirmed a trial court decision that employees of Ceridian Corporation's customers did not have standing to sue Ceridian after the payroll processing firm suffered a data breach. See ''[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=17477066302962080458 Reilly vs Ceridian]'', Ct.App. 3d Cir., No. 11-1738, 2011-12-12, (on appeal from case 2-10-cv-05142, U.S. Dist. Ct., Dist. N.J. 2010). See also ''[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=8287630509855765415 Cherny v. Emigrant Bank]'', 604 F.Supp. 2d 605, U.S. Dist. Ct., S.D.N.Y. 2009. Accessed April 17, 2012.</ref> The case remained on the California court's docket as of July 2012.<ref>Judge Koh, Lucy, [http://www.cand.uscourts.gov/CEO/cfd.aspx?7142 Case Mgmt Conference Further], 5:11-md-02250-LHK, In Re: iPhone/iPad Application Consumer Privacy Litigation, calendared for August 8, 2012. Accessed July 25, 2012.</ref>
===iTunes price-switching class action=== In June 2009, a group of consumers filed the class action suits ''Owens v. Apple, Inc.'' and ''Johnson v. Apple Inc.'' against Apple on behalf of American individuals who purchased iTunes [[gift card]]s and who were then unable to use the cards to purchase iTunes music at the price advertised on the card because Apple raised the price of the music after it sold the cards to consumers. The ''Johnson'' case<ref name="johnsonItunes">''Johnson v. Apple Inc.'', case 1-09-CV-146501, Cal. Sup. Ct., Santa Clara, 2009.</ref> absorbed the ''Owens'' case<ref name="owensCA">''[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=7744179693925522007 Owens v. Apple, Inc.]'', 09-cv-0479-MJR, U.S. Dist. Ct., S.D.Ill., 2009.</ref> and was settled on February 10, 2012, with payments to be made to consumers by Apple.<ref name="johnsonItunes" /> The ''Owens'' complaint alleged that Apple wrongfully marketed, distributed, and sold iTunes gift cards and songs through its online iTunes store, while representing that consumers could use the gift cards to purchase songs for [[USD|US]]$.99 a song and then, after such gift cards were purchased, raised the price on certain songs to $1.29 on April 7, 2009. The lawsuit's allegations included that Apple's conduct constituted breach of contract, violated the state consumer fraud statute, and violated consumer protection statutes of other states. The plaintiffs sought a $.30 refund remedy for each song that class members purchased using a $.99 iTunes card for which they were charged $1.29, plus their attorneys' fees and costs. Apple mounted a vigorous defense and sought to dismiss the suit but lost its motion in December 2009.<ref name="owensCA" /> Individuals are part of the class of plaintiffs if they are U.S. residents who purchased or received an iTunes Gift Card on which the card itself or its packaging contained language to the effect that songs were priced at $0.99 and who used the card to purchase one or more $1.29 songs from the iTunes Store on or before May 10, 2010.<ref>[https://www.johnsonitunessettlement.com/ImpDates.aspx Important Dates], Johnson iTunes Settlement. Accessed April 2, 2012.</ref> The settlement provides class members with an iTunes Store credit of $3.25 if an online claim form was submitted on or before September 24, 2012.<ref>[https://www.johnsonitunessettlement.com/APJ_NOT_WEB.pdf Class Notice], ''Johnson v. Apple Inc''. Class Action Settlement website, johnsonitunessettlement.com. Accessed April 2, 2012.</ref>
===Macbook MagSafe power adapter class action=== Apple settled a U.S. class action in 2011 regarding the older T-shaped MagSafe power adapters. Apple agreed to replace the adapters with newer adapters, and to compensate customers who were forced to buy replacement adapters.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20150201095650/https://www.adaptersettlement.com/ MagSafe Power Adaptor Settlement], Case No. C 09-01911 JW, class action information. Accessed 2015-07-04.</ref><ref>[http://support.apple.com/kb/ts4127 Apple's Power Adapter Replacement Program page]. Accessed 2015-07-04.</ref><ref>Crook, Jordan, [https://techcrunch.com/2011/11/10/class-action-lawsuit-forces-apple-to-replace-frayed-magsafe-power-cords/ Class-Action Lawsuit Forces Apple To Replace Frayed MagSafe Power Cords], [[TechCrunch]], November 10, 2011. Accessed 2015-07-04.</ref><ref>Kessler, Topher, [http://www.cnet.com/news/apple-agrees-to-magsafe-power-adapter-settlement/ Apple agrees to MagSafe power adapter settlement], [[CNET]], November 16, 2011. Accessed 2015-07-04.</ref>
===In-app purchases class action===
In 2011, five parents filed a class action suit against Apple for "in-app" purchases, which are purchases that can be made within applications ("apps"). The parents contended that Apple had not disclosed that the "free" apps that were to be used by children had the potential to rack up fees without the parent's knowledge. Potentially 23 million customers could make up the class. Apple offered a settlement option for customers who had fees in excess of $30.<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2013/feb/26/apple-settlement-children-in-app-purchases</ref> In 2011 The [[Federal Trade Commission]] (FTC) investigated similar claims.<ref>http://voices.washingtonpost.com/posttech/2011/02/ftc_chairman_to_probe_apple_ip.html</ref> This settled for $100 million.<ref name="theguardian.com">https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/mar/11/google-us-lawsuit-in-app-purchases</ref> The FTC's action lead to a payout of $32.5 million payout in February 2014.<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/jan/15/apple-practice-children-make-in-app-purchases</ref>
A similar case was filed by a parent in March 2014 against [[Google]].<ref name="theguardian.com"/>
==Trade practice==
===''Resellers v. Apple''=== In 2004, independent Apple resellers filed a lawsuit against Apple alleging the company used misleading advertising practices by using unfair business practices that harmed the resellers' sales while boosting Apple-owned outlets, in effect by favoring its own outlets over those of its resellers.<ref name="Oates">Oates, John, [https://www.theregister.co.uk/2004/06/16/apple_gets_sued/ Apple resellers are revolting], ''The Register'', June 16, 2004. Accessed May 2, 2007.</ref> The lawsuit claimed that Apple favored company-owned stores by providing significant discounts unavailable to independent dealers. The complaint alleged Apple's acts in favoring its own stores constituted breach of contract, false advertising, fraud, trade libel, defamation, and intentional interference with prospective economic advantage.<ref name="resellComplaints">{{cite web |url=http://www.tellonapple.org/complaint.php |archive-url=https://archive.is/20070317151756/http://www.tellonapple.org/complaint.php |archive-date=March 17, 2007 |title=Complaints |dead-url=yes |access-date=September 5, 2016}} in the reseller actions of 2003-2005. Accessed April 2, 2012.</ref> {{As of|2006}}, Apple reached settlements with all of the plaintiffs, including the bankruptcy trustee for one reseller that failed,<ref>''[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=14390486164838884170 In Re Macadam Computer, Inc.]'', U.S. Dist.Ct., N.D. Cal. 2007. Accessed April 2, 2012.</ref> while the former principal of that company appealed the bankruptcy court's approval of the settlement.<ref>Apple Computer, Inc., [http://media.corporate-ir.net/media_files/irol/10/107357/10K_2006.pdf Apple 10K], 2006, p. 41.</ref>
==Defamation==
===Libel dispute with Carl Sagan=== In 1994, engineers at Apple Computer [[List of Apple codenames|code-named]] the mid-level [[Power Macintosh 7100]] "[[Carl Sagan]]" after the popular astronomer in the hope that Apple would make "[[Billions and Billions: Thoughts on Life and Death at the Brink of the Millennium|billions and billions]]" with the sale of the computer.<ref name="Poundstone">Poundstone, William, Carl Sagan: A Life in the Cosmos, Henry Holt & Company, New York, 1999, pp. 363–364, 374–375. {{ISBN|0-8050-5766-8}}</ref> Apple used the name only internally, but Sagan was concerned that it would become a product endorsement and sent Apple a [[cease and desist|cease-and-desist]] letter.<ref>Poundstone, p. 363.</ref> Apple complied, but its engineers retaliated by changing the internal codename to "BHA" for "Butt-Head Astronomer".<ref name="Poundstone, p. 364">Poundstone, p. 364</ref><ref name="Linzmayer">Linzmayer, Owen, and Chaffin, Bryan, [http://www.macobserver.com/columns/thisweek/2004/20041120.shtml This Week in Apple History: November 14-20: McIntosh, IIe Killed, Butt-Head Astronomer], The Mac Observer, macobserver.com, November 15, 2004. Accessed 2012-7-23.</ref>
Sagan then sued Apple for [[defamation|libel]] in federal court. The court granted Apple's motion to dismiss Sagan's claims and opined in [[Obiter dictum|dicta]] that a reader aware of the context would understand Apple was "clearly attempting to retaliate in a humorous and satirical way", and that "It strains reason to conclude that Defendant was attempting to criticize Plaintiff's reputation or competency as an astronomer. One does not seriously attack the expertise of a scientist using the undefined phrase 'butt-head'."<ref name="Poundstone, p. 364" /><ref>''Sagan v. Apple Computer, Inc.'', CV 94-2180 LGB (BRx), 874 F.Supp. 1072, U.S. Dist. Ct., C.D.Cal. 1994; 1994 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 20154.</ref> Sagan then sued for Apple's original use of his name and likeness, but again lost and appealed that ruling.<ref name="Poundstone, p. 374">Poundstone, p. 374</ref> In November 1995, Apple and Sagan reached an out-of-court settlement and Apple's office of trademarks and patents released a conciliatory statement that "Apple has always had great respect for Dr. Sagan. It was never Apple's intention to cause Dr. Sagan or his family any embarrassment or concern".<ref>Poundstone, pp. 374–375.</ref> Apple's third and final code name for the project was "LaW", short for "Lawyers are Wimps".<ref name="Linzmayer" />
== Trademarks, copyrights, and patents ==
===Trademark===
====Apple Corps==== {{main|Apple Corps v. Apple Computer}} For nearly 30 years [[Apple Corps]] ([[The Beatles]]-founded record label and holding company) and Apple Inc. (then Apple Computer) litigated a dispute involving the use of the name "Apple" as a [[trademark]] and its association with music. In 1978, Apple Corps filed suit against Apple Computer for trademark infringement and the parties settled in 1981 with Apple Computer paying an undisclosed amount to Apple Corps, later revealed to be $80,000.<ref>Salkever, Alex, [http://www.businessweek.com/stories/2004-09-29/john-paul-george-ringo-dot-dot-dot-and-steve John, Paul, George, Ringo...and Steve?], ''Businessweek'', businessweek.com, September 30, 2004. Accessed 2012-7-23.</ref> A primary condition of the settlement was that Apple Computer agreed to stay out of the music business. In 1991, after Apple introduced the [[Apple IIgs]] with an [[Ensoniq]] music synthesizer chip, Apple Corps alleged the product to be in violation of the terms of their settlement. The parties then reached another settlement agreement and Apple paid Apple Corps around $26.5 million, with Apple agreeing it would not package, sell, or distribute physical music materials.<ref>Borland and Fried, [http://news.cnet.com/Apple-vs.-Apple-Perfect-harmony/2100-1027_3-5378401.html Apple vs. Apple: Perfect harmony?], [[CNET]] News, news.cnet.com, September 23, 2004.</ref>
In September 2003, Apple Corps again sued Apple Computer alleging Apple Computer had breached the settlement once more, this time for introducing [[iTunes]] and the [[iPod]]. Apple Corps alleged Apple Computer's introduction of the music-playing products with the [[iTunes Store|iTunes Music Store]] violated the terms of the previous agreement in which Apple agreed not to distribute music. The trial opened on March 29, 2006, in the UK.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4854408.stm Apple giants do battle in court], BBC News, news.bbc.co.uk, March 29, 2006. Accessed 2012-1-28.</ref> and ended on May 8, 2006, with the court issuing judgement in favor of Apple Computer.<ref>[http://www.zdnet.com/apple-computer-wins-court-battle-with-beatles-3039267671/ Apple Computer wins court battle with Beatles], [[Reuters]], ZDNet, zdnet.com, May 8, 2006. Accessed July 22, 2012.</ref><ref>Brandle, L. [http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/58508/apple-computer-triumphs-in-beatles-case Apple Computer Triumphs In Beatles Case], ''[[Billboard magazine|Billboard]]'', billboard.com, May 8, 2006.</ref> "[I] find no breach of the trademark agreement has been demonstrated," the presiding Justice Mann said.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hmcourts-service.gov.uk/judgmentsfiles/j4226/apple_v_apple_hc03c02428_0506.htm |title=Apple Corps Ltd. v. Apple Computer, Inc. |accessdate=2006-05-09 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070328175149/http://www.hmcourts-service.gov.uk/judgmentsfiles/j4226/apple_v_apple_hc03c02428_0506.htm |archivedate=March 28, 2007 |df=mdy }} version of [[Her Majesty's Courts Service]], hmcourts-service.gov.uk, Case No: HC03C02428, [2006] EWHC 996 (Ch). Accessed July 23, 2012.</ref><ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,200-2170977,00.html Transcript of full judgement] from ''[[The Times]]'', timesonline.co.uk, May 8, 2006.</ref>
On February 5, 2007, Apple Inc. and Apple Corps announced another settlement of their trademark dispute, agreeing that Apple Inc. would own all of the trademarks related to 'Apple' and would license certain of those trademarks back to Apple Corps for its continued use. The settlement ended the ongoing trademark lawsuit between the companies, with each party bearing its own legal costs, and Apple Inc. continuing to use the Apple name and logos on iTunes. The settlement's full terms were confidential.<ref>[https://www.apple.com/pr/library/2007/02/05Apple-Inc-and-The-Beatles-Apple-Corps-Ltd-Enter-into-New-Agreement.html Apple Inc. and The Beatles' Apple Corps Ltd. Enter into New Agreement], Apple Press Info, apple.com. Accessed July 23, 2012.</ref>
====Domain name disputes====
=====''appleimac.com''===== In an early [[domain name]] dispute, two months before announcing the [[iMac]] in July 1998, Apple sued then-teenager Abdul Traya. Having registered the domain name ''appleimac.com'' in an attempt to draw attention to the web-hosting business he ran out of his parents' basement, a note on Traya's site stated that his plan was to "generate traffic to our servers and try to put the domain to sale. [sic]"<ref name="Krigel">Lipton Krigel, Beth, [http://news.cnet.com/2100-1023-221921.html Teen in dispute with Apple over domain], CNET News, news.cnet.com, February 19, 1999. Accessed 2012-7-23.</ref> After a legal dispute lasting for nearly a year, Apple settled out of court, paying Traya's legal fees and giving him a 'token payment' in exchange for the domain name.<ref>[http://www.macobserver.com/news/99/april/990427/applevsteen.html Battle For Domain Name Between Apple And Teen Resolved], The Mac Observer, macobserver.com, April 27, 1999. Accessed 2012-1-28.</ref>
=====''itunes.co.uk''===== The Apple-Cohen dispute was a [[cybersquatting]] case where a top-level domain registrar's decision differed from prior decisions by awarding a domain name to a subsequent registrant (Apple), rather than to the prior registrant (Cohen). As the decision recounts,<ref name="CohenDecision">Full text of the ''Nominet-Cohen'' decision, including the full history of the use of the domain itunes.co.uk: [http://www.nominet.org.uk/digitalAssets/766_itunes.pdf Nominet Cohen-Apple decision].</ref> in November 2000, [[Benjamin Cohen (journalist)|Benjamin Cohen]] of [[CyberBritain]] registered the domain name ''itunes.co.uk''. The domain initially pointed to ''skipmusic.com'', and then to ''cyberbritain.com'', and was then inoperative for some time. Apple applied for a UK trademark for ''iTunes'' in October 2000 which was granted in March 2001, and then launched its UK iTunes music store service in 2004. Afterward, Cohen reactivated his registered domain name, redirecting it to iTunes' then-rival, [[Napster]];<ref name="nominetIndepExpert">Nominet UK Dispute Resolution Service, [http://www.nominet.org.uk/digitalAssets/766_itunes.pdf Decision of Independent Expert], DRS No. 02223, p. 3, March 10, 2005. Accessed 2012-7-23.</ref> later Cohen forwarded the domain name to his CyberBritain's cash back/rewards website.<ref name="CohenDecision"/>
In 2005, Apple took the matter to the Dispute Resolution Service operated by [[.uk]] [[domain name registry]] [[Nominet UK]] (the DRS), claiming that Apple had trademark rights in the name "iTunes" and that the use of the domain name by Cohen's company was abusive (these being the two tests under the DRS rules for prevailing in a matter where the complaint related only to the later use of a trademarked name).<ref name="nominetBackground">[http://www.nominet.org.uk/disputes/courtcases/itunes/ iTunes.co.uk Background], Nominet.org.uk., Accessed July 24, 2012</ref> The dispute was unresolved at the free [[mediation]] stage and so Apple paid for an independent expert to decide the case; the expert decided the dispute in Apple's favor.<ref name="CohenDecision"/><ref name="nominetIndepExpert"/>
Cohen thereafter launched a media offensive claiming the DRS was biased in favor of large businesses and made frequent threats of lawsuits against Nominet.<ref name="mccarthyNominet">McCarthy, Kieren, [https://www.theregister.co.uk/2005/05/27/itunes_no_nominet/ Cohen disputes UK registry's legitimacy], ''The Register'', Financial News, May 27, 2005.</ref> Cohen stated he believed that the DRS system was unfair for a number of reasons and would seek redress against Nominet with the [[High Court of Justice|High Court]] via [[judicial review]].<ref name="nominetBackground"/> Nominet stated that Cohen should appeal the case via the appeal process in the DRS. Cohen refused and, after several months, instead issued proceedings for judicial review.<ref name="richardsonNominet">Richardson, Tim, [https://www.theregister.co.uk/2005/06/17/itunes_nominet/ Nominet faces judicial review over itunes.co.uk ownership], ''The Register'', Music and Media, June 17, 2005.</ref> The High Court at first instance rejected Cohen's case in August 2005, noting that Cohen's company, Cyberbritain Group Ltd., should have used the appeal process forming part of Nominet's domain resolution service.<ref name="cohenHighCtOp">High Court of Justice, Queens Bench Division, Administrative Court, ''[http://www.nominet.org.uk/digitalAssets/30566_iTunes-Judicial-Review.pdf Cyberbritain Group Ltd. vs. Nominet UK Ltd.]'', CO Ref: CO/8360/2005, August 4, 2005.</ref> Afterward, Cohen's company asked for a rehearing and, as that case progressed, the interim domain name was transferred to Apple in accord with the expert's decision and thereafter pointed to the Apple music site. In November 2005, Cohen dropped all legal action against Apple.<ref name="cohenDropped">Richardson, Tim, [https://www.theregister.co.uk/2005/11/25/cohen_itunes/ Cohen ends legal bid for itunes.co.uk], Financial News, ''The Register'', November 25, 2005.</ref>
====Cisco Systems: iPhone mark==== In 2006, [[Cisco Systems]] and Apple negotiated over allowing Apple rights to use Cisco's [[Linksys iPhone]] trademark, but the negotiations stalled when Cisco pushed for the two products to be interoperable. Following the public unveiling of the [[iPhone|Apple iPhone]] at the 2007 [[Macworld – iWorld|Macworld Expo]], Cisco filed a lawsuit against Apple<ref>''[http://news.findlaw.com/wsj/docs/apple/ciscoaap110007cmp.html Cisco Systems Inc. v. Apple Inc.]'', 07-198, U.S. Dist.Ct., N.D. Cal. 2007.</ref> in January 2007, alleging Apple's iPhone name infringed on Cisco's iPhone trademark. Cisco alleged that Apple created a front company subsequent to their negotiations to try to acquire the rights another way, while Apple countered that there would be no [[Confusing similarity|likelihood of confusion]] between the two products, because Apple's iPhone product was the first cell phone with such a name, while Cisco's iPhone was a [[Voice over IP|VoIP]] phone.<ref>Reardon, Marguerite, and Krazit, Tom, [http://news.cnet.com/Cisco-sues-Apple-over-use-of-iPhone-trademark/2100-1047_3-6149285.html Cisco sues Apple over use of iPhone trademark], CNET News, news.cnet.com, January 10, 2007. Accessed 2012-7-22.</ref><ref>Rasch, Mark, [http://www.securityfocus.com/columnists/430 iPhone Trademarks: the Real Issues], securityfocus.com, January 22, 2007. Accessed April 2, 2012.</ref> Bloomberg reported Cisco's iPhone as a product marketed for less than $100 and part of the [[Linksys]] home [[Router (computing)|router]]s, enabling internet-based calls through [[Skype]] and [[Yahoo! Messenger]], and contrasted it with Apple's iPhone as a [[mobile phone]] which sold for around $600.<ref name="ciscoBloomberg">Levy, Ari, and Guglielmo, Connie, [https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aNrpjoPwYI0s Apple Can Sell IPhones This Year After Cisco Deal (Update3)], Bloomberg News, February 22, 2007. Accessed April 2, 2012.</ref> In February 2007, Cisco and Apple announced an agreement under which both companies would be allowed to use the iPhone name worldwide.<ref name="ciscoBloomberg" /><ref>Apple, Inc, [https://www.apple.com/pr/library/2007/02/21Cisco-and-Apple-Reach-Agreement-on-iPhone-Trademark.html Cisco and Apple Reach Agreement on iPhone Trademark], February 21, 2007. Accessed April 2, 2012.</ref><ref>[http://newsroom.cisco.com/dlls/2007/corp_022107b.html Cisco and Apple Reach Agreement on iPhone Trademark], Cisco press release, February 21, 2007. Accessed April 2, 2012.</ref>
====Sector Labs: use of Pod==== In March 2007, Apple [[Opposition proceeding|opposed]] a trademark application by [[Startup company|startup]] Sector Labs, which sought to register "Video Pod" as a mark identifying goods associated with a video projector product. Apple argued that the proposed mark was merely "descriptive" and should be denied because the registration would cause a likelihood of confusion with Apple's pre-existing "iPod" marks.<ref name="VideoPodBrief">Apple Inc., [http://ttabvue.uspto.gov/ttabvue/v?pno=91176027&pty=OPP&eno=87 Final Trial Brief], Video Pod matter, Opposition No. 91176027. Accessed April 11, 2012.</ref> In March 2012, the U.S. [[Trademark Trial and Appeal Board]] (TTAB) ruled in Apple's favor and denied Sector Labs' registration, finding that the "iPod" mark was "famous" and therefore entitled to broad protection under U.S. trademark law.<ref name="TTABvideoPod">Trademark Trial and Appeal Board, '[http://ttabvue.uspto.gov/ttabvue/v?pno=91176027&pty=OPP&eno=92 TTAB Decision]', Video Pod matter, Opposition No. 91176027, p. 47. Accessed July 25, 2012. The TTAB sustained Apple's opposition to the registration of the VIDEO POD mark under both Section 2(e)(1) and Section 2(d) of the Lanham Act.</ref>
====New York City "GreeNYC" logo==== In January 2008, Apple filed an opposition with the U.S. Trademark Trial and Appeal Board against [[New York City]]'s (NYC) trademark application for the "[[Big Apple]]" logo for NYC's [[GreeNYC]] initiative, by designer Blake E. Marquis.<ref>Larson, Erik, [http://articles.latimes.com/2008/apr/04/business/fi-apple4 Apple sues New York over logo], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', April 4, 2008. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref> NYC originally filed for its trademark: "a stylized apple design" for "[e]ducation services, namely, providing public service announcements on policies and practices of the City of New York in the field of environmentally sustainable growth" in May 2007, with an amendment filed in June 2007.<ref name="nyTM">[http://tdr.uspto.gov/search.action?sn=77179942 Trademark application and history, #77179942], NYC logo matter. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref> The TTAB's Notice of Publication was published in September 2007 and Apple filed an opposition with the TTAB the following January, claiming a likelihood of confusion.<ref>''Apple, Inc. opposition to NYC & Company, Inc.'', [http://ttabvue.uspto.gov/ttabvue/v?pno=91181984&pty=OPP Opp. No. 91181984]. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref> In June 2008, NYC filed a motion to amend its application to delete the leaf element from its design, leaving the stem, and the TTAB dismissed Apple's opposition and [[counterclaim]]s in accordance with the parties' [[stipulation]] in July 2008.<ref>USPTO, [http://ttabvue.uspto.gov/ttabvue/ttabvue-91181984-OPP-9.pdf TTAB dismissal of Apple opposition and counterclaim], NYC logo matter, July 28, 2008. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref> In November 2011, the TTAB issued NYC's trademark registration.<ref name="usptoNycTM">USPTO, [http://tarr.uspto.gov/servlet/tarr?regser=serial&entry=77179942 NYC Trademark Status], Trademark Trial and Appeal Board, February 23, 2010; and [http://tdr.uspto.gov/search.action?sn=77179942 USPTO TDR Portlet for Serial No. 77179942.] Accessed 2012-7-22.</ref>
====Victoria School of Business and Technology==== In September 2008, Apple sent a cease and desist letter<ref name="qcollege1">[http://www.qcollege.ca/about-q-college/blog/apples-and-oranges-vsbt-vs-apple-inc-logo-dispute Apples and Oranges: VSBT vs. Apple Inc. Logo Dispute] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426012647/http://www.qcollege.ca/about-q-college/blog/apples-and-oranges-vsbt-vs-apple-inc-logo-dispute |date=April 26, 2012 }}, Q College, January 14, 2011. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref> to the Victoria School of Business and Technology in [[Saanich, British Columbia]], claiming the school's logo infringed Apple's trademark rights and that the school's logo falsely suggested Apple had authorized the school's activities.<ref name="vicBusTech">[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/story/2008/10/06/bc-school-apple-logo.html No Apple for Vancouver Island School, Says Computer Corporation], [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]] News, October 6, 2008. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref> The logo in question featured the outline of an apple and a leaf, although the design incorporated a mountain, had three bumps on top of the apple instead of the two used by Apple, and had no bite out of the apple, unlike Apple's logo.<ref name="ctvFruit">CTV, [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/technology/will-apples-suit-against-bc-school-bear-fruit/article1063341/ Will Apple's suit against B.C. school bear fruit?], ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', October 6, 2008. Accessed July 22, 2012.</ref> In April 2011, the school reported it had settled its 3-year dispute with Apple, was launching a new logo under a new name, Q College, and was expanding its operations. The settlement's full terms were undisclosed.<ref name="vicTimesColonist">[http://www2.canada.com/victoriatimescolonist/news/business/story.html?id=b44805cb-d044-461c-883f-8f615d3079a5 Business school drops use of Apple's forbidden fruit], ''Times Colonist'', April 1, 2011. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref>
====Woolworths Limited logo==== [[File:Woolworths Stacked Tag RGB Positive HR.png|thumb|Woolworths' "W" logo, with stylized "W" trade mark, which Apple opposed]]
In October 2009, Apple disputed a trademark application by [[Woolworths Limited]] in [[Australia]] over the new logo for its supermarket chain [[Woolworths Supermarkets]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.woolworths.com.au/resources/woolworths+launches+new+look+after+21+years.pdf |title=Woolworths launches new look after 21 years |accessdate=2008-08-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091013091208/http://www.woolworths.com.au/resources/woolworths%2Blaunches%2Bnew%2Blook%2Bafter%2B21%2Byears.pdf |archivedate=October 13, 2009 |df=mdy }}, Woolworths Limited, 2008-8-22, Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref> a stylised "W", similar in shape to an apple.<ref>Sharp, Ari, [http://www.theage.com.au/national/woolies-shelves-safeway-brand-20080820-3ywj.html Woolies shelves Safeway brand], ''The Age'', theage.com.au, August 21, 2008. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref> Apple reportedly took objection to the breadth of Woolworths' application, which would allow it to brand products, including consumer electronics, with the logo.<ref name="woolies1">Lee, Julian, [http://www.theage.com.au/business/apple-bites-over-woolworths-logo-20091005-ghzr.html Apple bites over Woolworths logo], ''[[The Age]]'', theage.com.au, October 5, 2009. Accessed July 25, 2012.</ref> In April 2011, Woolworths amended its trademark application to remove various goods and services, such as "apparatus for recording, transmission or reproduction of sound or images"<ref>[http://pericles.ipaustralia.gov.au/atmoss/falcon_history.File_Details?p_tm_number=1258288&p_amend_no=141&p_table=SOC&p_search_no=219&p_extdisp=D&p_detail=DETAILED&p_mf_amend_no=028 Trade Mark History: 1258288], ipaustralia.gov.au, April 6, 2011. Accessed January 15, 2013.</ref> and Apple withdrew its opposition,<ref>[http://pericles.ipaustralia.gov.au/atmoss/falcon_history.File_Details?p_tm_number=1258288&p_amend_no=184&p_table=SOC&p_search_no=219&p_extdisp=D&p_detail=DETAILED&p_mf_amend_no=059 Trade Mark History: 1258288], ipaustralia.gov.au, April 18, 2011. Accessed 2013-1-15.</ref> allowing the trademark to proceed to registration.<ref>[http://pericles.ipaustralia.gov.au/atmoss/Falcon_Details.Print_TM_Details?p_tm_number=1258288&p_ExtDisp=D&p_Detail=DETAILED Trade Mark Details: 1258288], ipaustralia.gov.au, April 19, 2011. Accessed 2013-1-15.</ref> In August 2011 Woolworths introduced a shopping app for the iPhone,<ref>[http://www.woolworths.com.au/wps/wcm/connect/Website/Woolworths/Everyday+Services/iPhoneApp/ Woolworths App for iPhone] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120730072936/http://www.woolworths.com.au/wps/wcm/connect/Website/Woolworths/Everyday+Services/iPhoneApp/ |date=July 30, 2012 }}, woolworths.com.au, August 11, 2011. Accessed 2012-7-22.</ref> and, as of July 2012 continues to use the logo,<ref>[http://www.woolworths.com.au/wps/wcm/connect/webSite/Woolworths/ Woolworths] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100201214220/http://www.woolworths.com.au/wps/wcm/connect/webSite/Woolworths |date=February 1, 2010 }}, woolworths.com.au, April 12, 2012. Accessed 2012-7-22.</ref> including on the face of its iPhone app. The Woolworths smartphone app is also available on Apple's [[App Store (iOS)|App Store]]<ref name="wooleysApp">[https://itunes.apple.com/au/app/woolworths/id448267836?mt=8 Woolworth's App] in the Apple AppStore, itunes.apple.com. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref> where the logo is featured prominently; Apple closely manages its App Store offerings.<ref>Oreskovic, Alexei, and Shih, Gerry, [https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/06/29/us-google-chrome-idUSBRE85R1DN20120629 Google's Chrome browser to be available on Apple's iPad, iPhone], Reuters, reuters.com, June 29, 2012. Accessed 2012-7-25.</ref>
====''Apple v. DOPi'': lower-case i use==== In March 2010, an Australian Trademarks tribunal denied Apple's attempt to prevent a small company from trademarking the name DOPi for use on its laptop bags and cases for Apple products. Apple argued that the DOPi name — which is iPod spelled backwards — is too similar to its own product's name, the iPod.<ref name="mosesLeeNoI" />
====Proview: iPad trademark==== In 2006, Apple secured [[Taiwan]]ese rights to the iPad mark from the Taiwanese company Proview Electronics; in [[China]] the iPad mark was still owned by the subsidiary of Proview Electronics, [[Shenzhen]] company [[Proview International Holdings Ltd|Proview Technology]], as of April 2012.<ref name="proview1">[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-12-08/apple-loses-china-ipad-trademark-case/3721268 Apple loses China iPad trademark case], ''[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]'', abc.net.au, December 8, 2011. Accessed April 11, 2012.</ref><ref name="huffProview">Kurtenbach, Elaine [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/03/13/apple-proview-ipad-trademark_n_1342458.html Apple: Proview's iPad Trademark Demands Unfair], the ''[[Huffington Post]]'', March 13, 2012. Accessed 2012-4-11.</ref> Proview Technology sued Apple over the rights to the mark in China in 2011; Apple counter-sued but lost and then appealed, with the case before the [[Xicheng District|Xicheng]] district court, where Proview claimed $1.6 billion USD in damages.<ref name="proview2">Bonnington, Christina, [https://www.wired.com/gadgetlab/2012/02/chinese-firm-ipad-trademark/ Chinese Firm Demands $1.6 Billion from Apple in iPad Trademark Dispute], Wired.com, February 7, 2012. Accessed April 11, 2012.</ref> Apple paid Proview approximately $53,000 – $55,000 for the mark in 2009.<ref name="proview1" /><ref name="proview2" /> In February 2012, Proview sued Apple in the [[Superior Court of Santa Clara County|Santa Clara Superior Court]],<ref>''Proview Electronics Co. Limited, et al. v. Apple, Inc., et al.'', case 1-12-CV-219219, Ca. Superior Ct. (Santa Clara Co.), filed February 17, 2012. [http://www.sccaseinfo.org/pa6.asp?full_case_number=1-12-CV-219219&crumbs=Civil%20Index&crumbs=Party/Case%20Type%20Search&crumbs=Party/Case%20Type%20Results&crumbs=Cases%20Involving%20Proview%20Electronics%20Co.%20Limited Case Docket] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426120836/http://www.sccaseinfo.org/pa6.asp?full_case_number=1-12-CV-219219&crumbs=Civil%20Index&crumbs=Party%2FCase%20Type%20Search&crumbs=Party%2FCase%20Type%20Results&crumbs=Cases%20Involving%20Proview%20Electronics%20Co.%20Limited |date=April 26, 2012 }}. Accessed 2012-4-19.</ref> alleging several permutations of [[fraud]] (intentional misrepresentation, concealment, inducement) and unfair competition.<ref>Tsukayama, Hayley, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/technology/proview-files-suit-against-apple-in-us-court/2012/02/24/gIQALiBeXR_story.html Proview files suit against Apple in U.S. court], ''[[The Washington Post]]'', washingtonpost.com, February 24, 2012. Accessed 2012-4-19.</ref><ref>Tsukayama, Hayley, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/technology/proview-accuses-apple-of-fraud-unfair-competition/2012/02/28/gIQAKICsfR_story.html Proview accuses Apple of fraud, unfair competition], ''The Washington Post'', washingtonpost.com, February 28, 2012. Accessed 2012-4-19.</ref><ref>Mandalia, Ravi, [http://www.itproportal.com/2012/02/28/proview-amends-lawsuit-against-apple-seeks-global-ipad-name-rights/ Proview Amends Lawsuit Against Apple, Seeks Global iPad Name Rights], ITProPortal, itproportal.com, February 28, 2012. Accessed 2012-4-19.</ref> Apple paid $60 million to Proview to end the dispute in a court-mediated settlement in the Higher People's Court of [[Guangdong]] province; the U.S. case was thrown out of court.<ref>Lee, Melanie, and Shen, Samuel, [https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/07/02/apple-china-idUSL3E8I222420120702 UPDATE 4-Apple pays ,0 mln to settle China iPad trademark dispute], Reuters, reuters.com, July 2, 2012. Accessed July 25, 2012. See also "Guangdong Gaoyuan Chenggong Tiaojie Pingguo yu Weiguan IPAD Quanshu Jiufen An" (Guangdong Higher Court Succeeds in Mediating the Apple Proview Dispute over IPAD Trademarks), gdcourts.gov.cn, the [https://translate.google.com/translate?u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.gdcourts.gov.cn%2Fgdcourt%2Ffront%2Ffront%2521content.action%3Flmdm%3DLM20%26gjid%3D20120702104546916319&tl=en Guangdong Court's official statement] (via Google Translate); in [http://www.gdcourts.gov.cn/gdcourt/front/front%21content.action?lmdm=LM20&gjid=20120702104546916319 Chinese] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20121129221935/http://www.gdcourts.gov.cn/gdcourt/front/front!content.action?lmdm=LM20&gjid=20120702104546916319 |date=November 29, 2012 }}. The [[Trademark law of the People's Republic of China|Chinese trademark law]] (中华人民共和国商标法) is a fast developing field.</ref><ref>Zhang, Laney, [https://www.loc.gov/lawweb/servlet/lloc_news?disp3_l205403240_text China: Court Announces Apple and Proview Settlement of iPad Trademark Dispute], Global Legal Monitor, [https://www.loc.gov/law/ Law Library of Congress], loc.gov, July 16, 2012. Accessed 2012-7-25.</ref>
====Amazon "App Store"==== In 2011, Apple filed suit against [[Amazon.com]] alleging trademark infringement, unfair competition, and [[Trademark dilution|dilution]] under the [[Lanham Act]] and related California state law over Amazon's use of the "App Store" phrase relating to Amazon's "[[Amazon Appstore]] Developer Portal" and Amazon's alleged other similar uses of the phrase.<ref name="AppStore">''[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=14268514612110440332 Apple Inc v. Amazon.com Inc.]'', 11-1327, U.S. Dist. Ct., N.D.Ca., filed March 18, 2011. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref> In its complaint, Apple did not refer to "apps" as a common name, but described its applications store as a place consumers license "software programs or products"; Amazon countered in its answer that "app store" is a common phrase meaning a "place to buy apps".<ref>Pinguelo, Fernando M, and Hyman, Stacey A., [http://www.nmmlaw.com/pdf/Apple%20v.%20Amazon.com%20joint_norris_drinker_article.pdf Apple v. Amazon.com – The war for "App" Dominance Advances], ''Bloomberg Law Reports—Technology Law'', Bloomberg Finance L.P., Vol. 3, No. 11, 2011, from Norris, McLaughlin & Marcus, P.A., nmmlaw.com. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref> [[Reuters]] reported that [[Microsoft]] was opposing Apple's attempted registration of the phrase as a trademark and that part of the matter was before the Trademark Trial and Appeal Board (TTAB).<ref name="Levine">Levine, Dan, [https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/22/us-apple-amazon-lawsuit-idUSTRE72L07I20110322 Apple sues Amazon.com over APP STORE trademark], Reuters, reuters.com, March 22, 2011. Accessed 2012-7-22.</ref> Apple motioned the court for a [[preliminary injunction]] to bar Amazon from using the "App Store" name but, in July 2011, U.S. District Judge [[Phyllis Jean Hamilton|Phyllis Hamilton]], presiding over Apple's case against Amazon, denied Apple's motion.<ref name="AvAprelimInj">Apple Inc v. Amazon.com Inc., Order Denying Motion For Preliminary Injunction, No. C 11-1327 PJH, July 6, 2011. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref> In July 2012, the case was still in the discovery stage of litigation.<ref>Gold, Django, [http://www.law360.com/privacy/articles/362784/apple-wants-amazon-to-cough-up-docs-in-app-store-ip-row Apple Wants Amazon To Cough Up Docs In 'App Store' IP Row], Law360, law360.com, July 23, 2012. Accessed 2012-7-25.</ref>
In January 2013, Apple's claims were rejected by a US District judge, who argued that the company presented no evidence that Amazon had "[attempted] to mimic Apple's site or advertising", or communicated that its service "possesses the characteristics and qualities that the public has come to expect from the Apple APP STORE and/or Apple products"<ref name=ars-rejected>{{cite web|title=No app for that: Apple's false ad suit over Amazon Appstore thrown out|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2013/01/no-app-for-that-apples-false-ad-suit-over-amazon-appstore-thrown-out/|work=Ars Technica|accessdate=4 September 2013}}</ref> In July 2013, Apple dropped the lawsuit.<ref name="Bostic">{{cite web|last=Bostic |first=Kevin |url=http://appleinsider.com/articles/13/07/09/apple-drops-app-store-lawsuit-against-amazon-says-no-need-to-pursue-case |title=Apple drops 'App Store' lawsuit against Amazon, says no need to pursue case |publisher=Appleinsider.com |date=2013-07-09 |accessdate=2014-01-02}}</ref><!-- leave extra lines -->
===Trade secrets===
====''Apple v. Does''==== {{main|Apple v. Does}} Ultimately decided under the title ''O'Grady v. Superior Court'', the suit filed by Apple against unnamed bloggers raised the issue for the first time of whether bloggers hold the same protections against revealing sources that [[journalist]]s have. In November 2004, three popular [[weblog]] sites featuring [[Apple community|Apple rumors]] publicly revealed information about two unreleased Apple products, the [[Mac mini]] and an as yet unreleased product code-named ''Asteroid'', also known as ''Project Q97''. Apple [[subpoena]]ed three sites to force them to identify their confidential sources: ''[[Apple Insider]]'', ''Power Page'', and, separately, [[Think Secret]], which did no original reporting on the case and thus had no sources to reveal.<ref>[http://www.infozine.com/news/stories/op/storiesView/sid/7011/ News Publishers and Internet Industry Urge Reversal in Apple Case], ''Kansas City infoZine'', infozine.com, April 9, 2005. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref><ref>Marsal, Katie, [http://www.appleinsider.com/articles/09/06/23/report_details_apples_unusual_veil_of_secrecy.html Report details Apple's unusual veil of secrecy], Apple Insider, appleinsider.com, June 23, 2009. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref> In February 2005, a trial court in California decided that website operators do not have the same [[shield law]] protection as do other journalists. The journalists appealed and, in May 2006, the [[California Courts of Appeal|California Court of Appeal]] reversed the trial court's decision, ruling that activities in question were covered by the shield law.<ref>''O'Grady v. Superior Court'', 44 Cal. Rptr. 3d 72, 139 Cal.App. 4th 1423, modified by ''O'Grady v. Superior Court'', 140 Cal.App. 4th 675b, 2006.</ref>
====''Apple v. Think Secret''==== {{main|Think Secret}} {{further|Apple v. Does|Criticism of Apple Inc.#Think Secret lawsuit}} In ''Apple Computer v. DePlume'', a case illustrating one of Apple's methods of protecting its claims in [[trade secret]]s, Apple sued [[Think Secret]]'s parent company, the dePlume Organization LLC, and Think Secret's editor in January 2005,<ref>''Apple Computer, Inc., v. Nick Deplume, The Deplume Organization LLC, and Does 1-20'', case 1-05-CV-033341, Cal. Superior Ct, (Santa Clara), 2005.</ref> alleging misappropriation of trade secrets with regard to Think Secret's stories on a "headless iMac" and new version of [[iWork]].<ref name="HeadlessImac">Fried, Ina, [http://news.cnet.com/Apple-suit-foreshadows-coming-products/2100-1047_3-5513582.html Apple suit foreshadows coming products], CNET News, news.cnet.com, January 5, 2005. Accessed July 22, 2012.</ref> In response, DePlume filed a motion to dismiss the case based on [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] grounds under California's state [[Strategic lawsuit against public participation|Anti-SLAPP]] statute, a law designed to dispense with meritless legal claims attempting to silence valid exercises of freedom of speech.<ref name="TSantislapp">{{cite web|url=http://www.thinksecret.com/news/antislapp.html |title=Think Secret goes on offensive, asks to have Apple lawsuit dismissed |accessdate=2008-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080125174705/http://www.thinksecret.com/news/antislapp.html |archivedate=January 25, 2008 |df=mdy }}, Think Secret (via archive.org), 2005-3-4, January 25, 2008. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref><ref>''Apple Computer v. Deplume'',{{cite web|url=http://www.thinksecret.com/filings/antislappmemorandum.pdf |title=Defendant The Deplume Organization LLC's Memorandum of Points and Authorities in Support of Special Motion to Strike Complaint Pursuant to California Anti-Slapp Statute, CCP§ 425.16 |accessdate=2007-03-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070305181816/http://www.thinksecret.com/filings/antislappmemorandum.pdf |archivedate=March 5, 2007 |df=mdy }}, Think Secret (via archive.org), April 12, 2005. Accessed 2012-7-27. Think Secret's archived web page has links to their{{cite web|url=http://www.thinksecret.com/news/antislapp.html |title=filings |accessdate=2008-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080125174705/http://www.thinksecret.com/news/antislapp.html |archivedate=January 25, 2008 |df=mdy }} .</ref> In late 2007, Think Secret announced "Apple and Think Secret have settled their lawsuit, reaching an agreement that results in a positive solution for both sides. As part of the confidential settlement, no sources were revealed and Think Secret will no longer be published".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thinksecret.com/news/settlement.html |title=Apple, Think Secret settle lawsuit |accessdate=2012-07-23 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071223063415/http://www.thinksecret.com/news/settlement.html |archivedate=December 23, 2007 |df=mdy }}, Think Secret (via archive.org), December 20, 2007. Accessed 2012-7-23.</ref><!-- leave extra lines -->
===Copyright===
====''Apple v. Franklin''==== {{main|Apple Computer, Inc. v. Franklin Computer Corp.}} ''Apple v. Franklin'' established the fundamental basis of copyright of computer software, even if it was provided only as object code or in [[firmware]]. In 1982, Apple filed a lawsuit against [[Franklin Computer Corp.]], alleging that Franklin's ACE 100 personal computer used illegal copies of the [[Apple II]]'s [[operating system]] and [[Read-only memory|ROM]]. The case was decided in Franklin's favor but reversed by the Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.<ref>''Apple Computer, Inc. v. Franklin Computer Corp.'', 714 F.2d 1240, 3d Cir., 1983.</ref>
====Object code cases and conflicts of law==== {{See also|Apple Computer, Inc. v. Mackintosh Computers Ltd.}} Apple's litigation over [[overhead code|object code]]<ref>Compare [[overhead code|object code]] with [[object file]]</ref> contributed to the development of contemporary copyright law because the company's object code cases brought different results in different courts, creating a [[conflict of laws]] that resulted in international litigation. In the 1980s, Apple litigated two copyright cases with central issues that included the question of whether object code (as contrasted with [[source code]]) of a computer program is subject to copyright laws. A third case in which Apple was not a party but that involved the Apple decisions followed in New Zealand. The specific cases were ''Computer Edge Pty. Ltd. v Apple Computer Inc.'' (1986, Australia) ("''Computer Edge''"),<ref name="computerEdge">''Computer Edge Pty. Ltd. v Apple Computer Inc.'', 65 ALR 33, 1986; F.S.R. 537, 1986, High Court of Australia.</ref> ''Apple Computer Inc. v Mackintosh Computers Ltd.'', (Canada, 1987) ("''Apple v. Mackintosh''"),<ref name="ApplevMac">''Apple Computer Inc. v Mackintosh Computers Ltd.'', 44 DLR (4th) 74 Federal Court of Appeal, 1987, Canada, (later affirmed, [http://scc.lexum.org/en/1990/1990scr2-209/1990scr2-209.html Supreme Court of Canada] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120609121231/http://scc.lexum.org/en/1990/1990scr2-209/1990scr2-209.html |date=June 9, 2012 }}, [1990] 2 S.C.R. 209). Accessed July 22, 2012.</ref> and ''IBM v. Computer Imports Ltd.'' ("''IBM v. Computer Imports''"), (New Zealand, 1989).<ref name="nzIBM">''International Business Machines Corporation v.
