Computer Imports Limited'', 2 NZLR 395, 409, 1989.</ref>
In the ''Computer Edge'' case, the Australian court decided against the then-prevailing opinions in other courts (the U.K., Canada, South Africa, and the U.S.) and ruled object code was not copyrightable,<ref name="CE2">In ''Computer Edge'' the court looked to 1986 161 CLR 171 (test in Exxon for literary work is "not intended to establish a comprehensive or exhaustive definition of literary work for copyright purposes" per Mason and Wilson JJ (Aus.)).</ref> while the [[Supreme Court of Canada]] in ''Apple v. Mackintosh'' reversed its earlier decisions and ruled that because object code was a translation of source code and embodied in a silicon chip, it was therefore a translation of an original literary work expressed in a material form and unauthorized reproduction of the object code was therefore an infringement of copyright. The Canadian court opined that programs within [[Read-only memory|ROM]] silicon chips are protected under the [[Copyright Act of Canada]] and the conversion from the source code into object code is a form of [[translation]]. It further held that such translation does not include the expression of an idea in another form, but rather only applies to the expression of an idea in another language, and that a translation has a one-to-one correspondence between works that are expressed in two different languages.
In these conflict of laws cases, Apple met with conflicting international judicial opinions: an Australian court decision conflicted with a Canadian court decision on the copyrightability of object code. In ''IBM v. Computer Imports'', the [[High Court of New Zealand]] then considered these prior decisions and sided with the Canadian decision in ruling that, although object code is not an original literary work in its own right, it is a reproduction of source code in material form and therefore an infringement of copyright takes place if it is copied without the authorization of the copyright owner.<ref name="nzIBM"/> Such legal conflicts affected not only Apple, but all other software companies as well, and the conflicts remained unresolved until the creation of an international legal regime embodied in further changes to national copyright laws, which ultimately made object code subject to copyright law.<ref name="copyrtChgs">The 1994 Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights ([[Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights|TRIPs]]), the 1991 European Economic Council Directive on the Legal Protection of Computer Programs ("[[Computer Programs Directive|EC Directive]]"), the [[Copyright Act of Canada]], the New Zealand [[Copyright Act 1994]], and other national copyright law revisions.</ref> These revisions of law in favor of making object code subject to copyright law are still controversial.<ref name="Corbett">Corbett, Susan, [http://www.victoria.ac.nz/sacl/research/seminars/documents2007/sc_230307.pdf What if Object Code Had Been Excluded from Protection as a Literary Work in Copyright Law?], a paper for presentation at the 4th Annual Intellectual Property Conference: ''Rewriting History: Counterfactuals and Alternative Stories in Intellectual Property and Cyberspace Law'', Michigan State Univ. College of Law, 2007:3. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref> The revisions also form the technical underpinnings (via the [[Digital Millennium Copyright Act]] (DMCA) and the [[Electronic Communications Privacy Act]])<ref>The Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) criminalizes circumvention of [[Digital rights management]] (DRM) for copyrighted works and controls access to copyrighted software. Digital Millennium Copyright Act, Pub. L. 105-304 (1998); 17 U.S.C. § 1201(a)(1) (2006).</ref> for the legal notions of electronic privacy violation<ref>''[[Robbins v. Lower Merion School District]]'', [http://lmsd.org/documents/news/100503_l3_report.pdf Initial LANrev System Findings] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100615100827/http://lmsd.org/documents/news/100503_l3_report.pdf |date=June 15, 2010 }}, LMSD Redacted Forensic Analysis, L-3 Services for LMSD's counsel, May 2010, p. 15. Accessed July 23, 2012. The school used its technology to track licensed copyrighted software, among other things.</ref> and computer trespass, as well as the further development of anti-hacking law-making such as the [[Patriot Act]] and the [[Convention on Cybercrime]].<ref>Lloyd, Ian J., Information Technology Law, 5th ed., Chapters 10, 17, and 18, 2008. {{ISBN|978-0-19-929977-5}}.</ref><ref>Zingales, Nicolo, [http://ijclp.net/ojs/index.php/ijclp/article/download/35/19 DRM Misuse: An Emerging Doctrine In Search For Principles] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111133703/http://ijclp.net/ojs/index.php/ijclp/article/download/35/19 |date=November 11, 2013 }}, International Journal of Communications Law and Policy, 2011:14. Accessed July 23, 2012. See also ''Microsoft Corp. v. Rechanik'', 249 F. App'x 476 (7th Cir. 2007). Accessed 2012-7-27. (Distributor of counterfeit software violated copyright laws.); and ''[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=13611490115081845690 US v. Kononchuk]'', 485 F.3d 199 (3d Cir. 2007). Accessed 2012-7-27. (Software counterfeiters face criminal liability.)</ref>
====''Apple v. Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard''==== {{main|Apple Computer, Inc. v. Microsoft Corporation}} In 1988, after the introduction of Microsoft's [[Windows 2.0]], Apple filed a lawsuit against Microsoft and [[Hewlett-Packard]] alleging that [[Microsoft Windows]] and HP's [[HP NewWave|NewWave]] violated Apple's copyrights in the [[Macintosh]] [[user interface]]. Cited, among other things, was the use of overlapping and resizable windows in Windows 2.0. The case was one of the "[[look and feel]]" copyright lawsuits of the 1980s. After several years in court, Apple's claims against Microsoft were dismissed, primarily due to a license [[John Sculley]] had negotiated with [[Bill Gates]] for Windows 1.0. The decision was upheld on appeal in 1994, but legal disputes on this topic were still ongoing until 1997, when the two companies came to a wide-ranging agreement that included Microsoft buying non-voting Apple stocks.<ref name="applemscnet">Kawamoto, Dawn; Heskett, Ben; Ricciuti, Mike. [http://news.cnet.com/MS-to-invest-150-million-in-Apple/2100-1001_3-202143.html MS to invest ,0 million in Apple], CNET News, news.cnet.com, August 6, 1997. Accessed July 22, 2012.</ref><ref name="applemsfindlaw">{{cite web|url=http://contracts.corporate.findlaw.com/agreements/apple/microsoft.1997.08.05.html |title=Apple-Microsoft Preferred Stock Purchase Agreement |accessdate=2007-01-26 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020811140307/http://contracts.corporate.findlaw.com/agreements/apple/microsoft.1997.08.05.html |archivedate=August 11, 2002 |df=mdy }}, FindLaw (via archive.org), corporate.findlaw.com, August 5, 1997. Accessed July 22, 2012.</ref>
====''Xerox v. Apple Computer''==== ''Xerox Corp. v. Apple Computer'' was a 1989 case where Xerox sued Apple over its [[graphical user interface]] (GUI) copyrights.<ref name="xerox">''[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=3538913398421433687 Xerox Corp. v. Apple Computer, Inc.]'', 734 F. Supp. 1542 (N.D. Cal. 1990). Accessed December 21, 2012.</ref> A federal district court dismissed Xerox's claims without addressing whether Apple's GUI infringed Xerox's.<ref name="xeroxNYT1">Fisher, Lawrence. [https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/15/business/company-news-xerox-sues-apple-computer-over-macintosh-copyright.html Xerox Sues Apple Computer Over Macintosh Copyright], ''The New York Times'', nytimes.com, December 15, 1989. Accessed 2012-12-21.</ref><ref name="xeroxNYT2">Pollack, Andrew, [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0CE3D91E38F937A15750C0A966958260 Most of Xerox's Suit Against Apple Barred], ''The New York Times'', nytimes.com, March 24, 1990. Accessed 2012-12-21.</ref>
====''OdioWorks v. Apple''==== The ''OdioWorks'' case<ref name="OdioCase">''OdioWOrks v. Apple'', case C-09-1818, U.S. Dist.Ct., N.D. Cal. 2009.</ref> was one of the first high-profile cases illustrating Apple's attempts to employ federal police power in its litigation practices by invoking the anti-circumvention provisions of the Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) as a means of shielding its intellectual property from [[reverse engineering]].<ref name="effUnintended">Von Lohmann, Fred, [https://www.eff.org/files/eff-unintended-consequences-12-years.pdf Unintended Consequences: Twelve Years under the DMCA,] [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]], eff.org, 2010-2. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref> In November 2008, Apple sent a cease-and-desist letter to BluWiki, a non-commercial [[wiki]] provider,<ref name="McNamara">McNamara, Paul, [http://www.networkworld.com/community/node/43762 Apple takes legal heel off throat of wiki operator], Network World, networkworld.com, July 22, 2009. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref> alleging BluWiki infringed Apple's copyrights in publishing a discussion of how to make the latest iPods interoperate with other software and that, by so doing, violated the DMCA.<ref name="effBluWiki">[https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2008/11/apple-confuses-speech-dmca-violation Apple Confuses Speech with a DMCA Violation], EFF, eff.org, November 25, 2008. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref> In April 2009, OdioWorks, the operators of BluWiki, backed by the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] (EFF), defensively sued Apple seeking a declaration of non-infringement and non-circumvention.<ref name="eff042709">[https://www.eff.org/press/archives/2009/04/27 Wiki Operator Sues Apple Over Bogus Legal Threats], EFF, eff.org, April 27, 2009. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref> In July 2009, Apple ceased claiming infringement, stating it was "withdrawing [Apple's] takedown notifications" and that "Apple no longer has, nor will it have in the future, any objection to the publication of the itunesDB Pages which are the subject of the OdioWorks complaint".<ref name="AppleOdioworksLtr">''[https://www.eff.org/files/filenode/odio_v_apple/apple_letter.pdf Re: OdioWOrks v. Apple]'', case C-09-1818, U.S. Dist.Ct., N.D. Cal., 2008-9-8, via eff.org. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref> After Apple withdrew its complaint and cited code obsolescence as a contributing factor in its decision to withdraw, BluWiki then republished its discussion of the issue.<ref name="Clayburn">Clayburn, Thomas, [http://www.informationweek.com/news/218600244 Apple Drops Complaint Against BluWiki], ''[[Information Week]]'', informationweek.com, July 22, 2009. Accessed 2012-7-22.</ref> The EFF noted, "While we are glad that Apple retracted its baseless legal threats, we are disappointed that it only came after 7 months of censorship and a lawsuit".<ref name="eff072209">[https://www.eff.org/press/archives/2009/07/22-0 Apple Withdraws Threats Against Wiki Site], EFF, eff.org, July 22, 2009. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref><!-- leave extra lines -->
===Trade dress===
===={{anchor|Apple v. Digital Research}}GEM "look and feel" suit==== [[Image:Gem 11 Desktop.png|thumb|right|The design of the [[Graphics Environment Manager|GEM]] 1.1 desktop was a copy of that of the Mac GUI.]] Prevailing in an early [[copyright infringement]] suit in the mid-1980s, Apple forced [[Digital Research]] to alter basic components in Digital Research's [[Graphics Environment Manager]] ("GEM"), almost a direct copy of the Macintosh's graphical user interface (GUI), or "look and feel". Features Digital Research removed from GEM as a result of the lawsuit included [[hard disk drive|disk drive]] icons on the desktop, movable and resizable windows in the file manager, shading in the title bars, and window open/close animations. In addition, visual elements including the [[scrollbar|scrollbar thumbs]] and the window close button were changed to be less similar to those in the Mac GUI.<ref name="gui-history">Reimer, Jeremy, [http://www.living-information.de/pdf/gui_history.pdf ''A History of the GUI''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719055252/http://www.living-information.de/pdf/gui_history.pdf |date=July 19, 2011 }}, Ars Technica, arstechnica.com, May 5, 2005. Accessed July 23, 2012.</ref>
====''Apple v. eMachines''==== In 1999, Apple successfully sued [[eMachines]], whose [[eOne]] too closely resembled the then-new iMac's [[trade dress]].<ref>''Apple Computer Inc. v. eMachines Inc.'', case 99-CV-20839, U.S. Dist.Ct., N.D. Cal., filed 1999-8-19, (settled).</ref><ref>Kanellos, Michael, [http://news.cnet.com/Apple-sues-eMachines-for-iMac-look-alike/2100-1040_3-230054.html Apple sues eMachines for iMac look-alike], CNET News, news.cnet.com, August 19, 1999. Accessed 2012-7-22.</ref> The eOne was taken off the market, resulting in eMachines' losing the ability to sell the eOne as intended. In eMachines' [[EDGAR]] statement for May 1, 2001, eMachines stated that its "net loss for the first quarter of 2001 was $31.1 million, or $0.21 per share, compared to a loss of $11.9 million, or $0.13 per share, in the first quarter of 2000", and that these results "reflect the substantial discounts and incentives that we gave to retailers to enable liquidation of product inventories".<ref name="eMachines,-Inc-May-2001-S-3/A">{{cite web|url=http://edgar.secdatabase.com/2776/101706201500153/filing-main.htm |title=eMachines, Inc, Form S-3/A, Filing Date May 1, 2001 |publisher=secdatabase.com |accessdate =May 14, 2018}}</ref><ref>Miles, Stephanie, [http://news.cnet.com/Apple-settles-suits-over-iMac-knockoffs/2100-1040_3-237717.html Apple settles suits over iMac knockoffs], CNET News, news.cnet.com, March 8, 2000. Accessed July 22, 2012.</ref><ref>Before the suit was settled, an analysis of the claims appeared in the ''National Law Journal'': Coolley, Brady, and Campagna,{{cite web|url=http://www.jonesday.com/files/Publication/ca36aa41-cd43-4a0e-8d4e-af91f85d0fc2/Presentation/PublicationAttachment/7a6d9a54-7877-4b76-a4e6-469176cb16a5/iMacs.pdf |title=Cases suggest iMacs' trade dress merits protection |accessdate=2010-04-27 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615143432/http://www.jonesday.com/files/Publication/ca36aa41-cd43-4a0e-8d4e-af91f85d0fc2/Presentation/PublicationAttachment/7a6d9a54-7877-4b76-a4e6-469176cb16a5/iMacs.pdf |archivedate=June 15, 2011 |df=mdy }}, [[Jones Day]], January 31, 2000. Accessed 2012-7-22.</ref><!-- leave extra lines -->
===Patent===
====''Creative Technology v. Apple, Inc.'' (menu structure)==== In a dispute illustrating the nature of claims, defenses, and counterclaims for [[patent infringement]] based on arguments of [[prior art]] and [[First to file and first to invent|first to file]], rival digital music player maker [[Creative Technology]] sued Apple in May 2006 for Apple's alleged infringement of Creative's [[Creative Zen|Zen]] patent<ref name="creativeoriginal">Creative Technology LTD Original patent #US006928433: [http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO1&Sect2=HITOFF&d=PALL&p=1&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsrchnum.htm&r=1&f=G&l=50&s1=6928433.PN.&OS=PN/6928433&RS=PN/6928433 Automatic hierarchical categorization of music by metadata], USPTO, uspto.gov, filed January 5, 2001. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref> claiming Apple infringed Creative's patent for the menuing structures on an [[MP3]] player.<ref name="creativeTechSuit">''Creative Technology Ltd. v. Apple Computer Inc.'', case 4:06CY3218, U.S. Dist.Ct., N.D. Cal. May 15, 2006.</ref> Creative claimed it began using its menuing method on its [[Creative NOMAD|Nomad player]]s in September 2000, approximately a year prior to Apple's first iPod release in October 2001.<ref name="arik">Hesseldahl, Arik, [http://www.businessweek.com/stories/2006-05-16/creative-technology-takes-on-apple Creative Technology Takes on Apple], ''Businessweek'', businessweek.com, May 17, 2006. Accessed 2012-7-22.</ref> Creative, a Singapore-based consumer electronics group, also filed a trade complaint with the [[United States International Trade Commission]] (ITC) against Apple.<ref name="itc1">''Certain Portable Digital Media Players'', 71 Fed. Reg. 34,390, June 8, 2006 (notice); Apple filed an ITC countersuit for Creative's alleged infringement of U.S. Patent Nos. 7,046,230, 5,341,293, 5,898,434, and 6,282,646: ''Notice of Investigation'', Inv.No. 337-TA-543, U.S. Int'l Trade Comm'n, June 21, 2005. See also: ''In the Matter of Certain Portable Digital Media Players'', Notice of Investigation, Inv. No. 337-TA-573, U.S. Int'l Trade Comm'n, 2006-6-8.</ref><ref name="kawamoto">Kawamoto, Dawn, [http://news.cnet.com/ITC-to-investigate-Apple%2C-says-Creative/2100-1047_3-6083590.html ITC to investigate Apple, says Creative], CNET News, news.cnet.com, June 14, 2006. Accessed 2012-7-22.</ref> Creative asked for a court [[injunction]] to block the import and sale of Apple's iPod and [[iPod nano]] in the United States and for money damages for past sales. Apple filed a countersuit against Creative on similar grounds.<ref name="appleCounterCreative">Burton, John, [http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/12872050/ Apple counter-sues Creative], Gadgets – [[MSNBC.com]] story from ''The Financial Times Ltd.'', May 19, 2006. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/05/18/technology/18iht-ipod.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=Apple%20sues%20iPod%20rival%20over%20patents&st=cse Apple sues iPod rival over patents], ''The New York Times'' (''[[International Herald Tribune]]''), nytimes.com, May 18, 2006. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ipodhacks.com/article.php?sid=1852 |title=Creative Files Suit Against Apple For Patent Infringement |accessdate=2006-05-26 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100107175245/http://www.ipodhacks.com/article.php?sid=1852 |archivedate=January 7, 2010 |df=mdy }}, iPod Hacks, May 16, 2006. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref>
In August 2006, Apple and Creative settled the suit with Apple agreeing to pay Creative $100 million USD for the right to implement Creative's method of sorting songs on the iPod.<ref name="klemens">Klemens, Ben, [http://128.197.26.34/law/central/jd/organizations/journals/scitech/volume141/documents/Klemens.pdf The Rise of the Information Processing Patent] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111133444/http://128.197.26.34/law/central/jd/organizations/journals/scitech/volume141/documents/Klemens.pdf |date=November 11, 2013 }}, 14 Boston Univ. ''Jour. Science & Tech. Law'' 1, 2008. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref><ref name="krazit06">Krazit, Tom [http://news.cnet.com/2100-1047_3-6108901.html Apple settles with Creative for ,0 million], CNET News, news.cnet.com, September 23, 2006. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref> The settlement effectively ended the patent dispute and five other pending lawsuits between the two companies. Creative also secured an agreement to participate in the "Made for iPod" program by producing accessories for the iPod.<ref>Apple, Inc., [https://www.apple.com/pr/library/2006/08/23Apple-Creative-Announce-Broad-Settlement-Ending-Legal-Disputes-Between-the-Companies.html Apple & Creative Announce Broad Settlement Ending Legal Disputes Between the Companies], apple.com, August 23, 2006. Accessed 2012-7-22.</ref>
====Typhoon Touch Technologies (touch screen)==== In June 2008, Apple was named among others as a defendant in a suit brought by plaintiff Typhoon Touch Technologies in the federal [[United States District Court for the Eastern District of Texas|U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Texas]] alleging patent infringement in portable [[touch screen]] technology.<ref name="typhoonSuit">''Typhoon Touch Techs., Inc. v. Dell, Inc.'', case 6:07-cv-546, U.S. Dist.Ct., E.D.Tex. (Tyler Division), filed October 23, 2008. Plaintiff's complaint identified the patents as U.S. Patent No. 5,379,057: "Portable Computer with Touch Screen and Computer System Employing Same," and U.S. Patent No. 5,675,362: "Portable Computer with Touch Screen and Computing System Employing Same".</ref> The suit illustrated the vagaries of litigating patent licensing and [[Royalties|royalty]] collection issues in the commercial exploitation of intellectual property rights. Ultimately, Typhoon could not prevail against patent defense arguments of prior art and [[obviousness]] and earned itself a reputation as a [[patent troll]].<ref name="Shrestha">Shrestha, Sannu, [http://www.columbialawreview.org/assets/pdfs/110/1/Shrestha.pdf Trolls Or Market-Makers? An Empirical Analysis Of Nonpracticing Entities] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120415013519/http://www.columbialawreview.org/assets/pdfs/110/1/Shrestha.pdf |date=April 15, 2012 }}, ''Columbia Law Review'', columbialawreview.org, Vol. 110, p. 114, 2010, Appendix B.1., November 22, 2009. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref> Typhoon acquired two pre-existing patents, (filed in 1993 and 1994 and issued in 1995 and 1997), in mid-2007 for $350,000 plus a percentage of collected licensing fees.<ref name="redflags">Harris, Larry, [http://seekingalpha.com/article/84206-red-flags-at-typhoon-touch-technologies Red Flags at Typhoon Touch Technologies], Seeking Alpha, seekingalpha.com. July 9, 2008. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref> The patents had languished for some time and were not being policed; shortly after Typhoon acquired the patents, it began enforcement by bringing suit against exploiters of the technology who had not paid licensing fees. Typhoon was successful in its patent infringement suits against some small companies, and then expanded its litigation to go after larger ones. Typhoon alleged that Apple and others used its patented technology inventions without permission. Typhoon originally filed the suit in December 2007 against [[Dell]] after settling with some smaller companies but, in mid-2008, amended its complaint to add Apple,<ref>Plaintiff's Third Amended Complaint for Patent Infringement at pp. 5–6, ''Typhoon Touch Techs., Inc. v. Dell, Inc.'', case 6:07-cv-00546-LED, E.D.Tex., March 6, 2009. (Asserted, inter alia, that the iPhone infringes U.S. Patent Nos. 5,379,057 and 5,675,362.); and see Seaman, Christopher B., [http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1575805& Reconsidering the Georgia-Pacific Standard for Reasonable Royalty Patent Damages], ''BYU Law Review'', No. 5, p. 1661, 2010; Chicago-Kent Intellectual Property, Science & Technology Research Paper No. 10-030, 2011-2-1, via papers.ssrn.com. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref> [[Fujitsu]], [[Toshiba]], [[Lenovo]], [[Panasonic Corporation|Panasonic]], [[HTC]], [[Palm, Inc.|Palm]], [[Samsung Electronics|Samsung]], [[Nokia]], and [[LG Corp|LG]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://app.quotemedia.com/quotetools/newsStory.go?storyId=11549290&topic=TYPT&symbology=null&cp=null |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080627212505/http://app.quotemedia.com/quotetools/newsStory.go?storyId=11549290&topic=TYPT&symbology=null&cp=null |dead-url=yes |archive-date=June 27, 2008 |title=Apple Inc. and 9 Others Added to Greatly Expanded Dell, Inc. Patent Infringement Suit Brought by Typhoon Touch Technologies, Inc. |access-date=September 5, 2016}}, ''Business Wire'', QuoteMedia.com (via archive.org), June 23, 2008. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref><ref>Thompson Financial News, [http://www.moneyam.com/action/news/showArticle?id=3055732 Apple, Nokia, others added to Typhoon Touch lawsuit launched vs Dell], ''[[Thomson Financial]]'' via moneyam.com, June 24, 2008. Accessed 2012-7-22.</ref> In 2010, Apple settled with Typhoon for an undisclosed sum and was then dismissed from the litigation as of September 2010.<ref>Marks, Joseph, [http://www.law360.com/articles/193783/apple-strikes-deal-in-typhoon-touch-screen-ip-spat Apple Strikes Deal In Typhoon Touch-Screen IP Spat], Law360, law360.com, New York, September 15, 2011. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref> The other large companies were able to rebuff Typhoon's claims, and Typhoon ceased doing business in 2008 after the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC) suspended its trading in a fraud investigation.<ref>[https://www.sec.gov/litigation/suspensions/2008/34-58187.pdf SEC temporary suspension of Typhoon Touch Trading], SEC, sec.gov, July 18, 2008. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref><ref name="tttFilings">[https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1352588/000122150808000051/form15aug212008.htm Securities registration termination [Section 12(g)] Acc-no: 0001221508-08-000051 (34 Act)], 15-12G filing of firm [https://www.sec.gov/cgi-bin/browse-edgar?filenum=000-52130&action=getcompany 000-52130 081032074], SEC records of Typhoon Touch Technologies, SEC, sec.gov, August 21, 2008. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref>
====''Nokia v. Apple'' (wireless, iPhone)==== In October 2009, Nokia Corporation sued Apple for Apple's infringement of Nokia's patents relating to wireless technology;<ref name="nokiaApple">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/8321058.stm Nokia suing Apple over the iPhone], BBC News, news.bbc.co.uk, October 22, 2009; article now at [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/8408696.stm Apple and Nokia's battle hots up], BBC News, news.bbc.co.uk, 2009-12-11. Accessed 2012-3-26.</ref> Apple countersued Nokia in December 2009.<ref name="appleNokia">[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-13759612 Nokia and Apple settle patent dispute], BBC News, news.bbc.co.uk, December 11, 2009. Accessed 2012-3-26.</ref> The two companies engaged in nearly two-years of litigation and both parties amended their claims multiple times and in multiple courts before finally settling in June 2011. For an undisclosed amount of cash and future ongoing iPhone royalties to be paid by Apple, Nokia agreed to settle, with Apple's royalty payments retroactively back-payable to the iPhone's introduction in 2007, but with no broad cross-licensing agreement made between the companies. Apple only agreed to cross-license some patents to Nokia. "Apple said in a statement today that Nokia will have a license to some technology, "but not the majority of the innovations that make the iPhone unique". Apple gets a license to some of Nokia's patents, including ones that were deemed essential to industry standards on mobile phones.<ref name="nokiaAppleSettlement">ben-Aaron, Diana and Pohjanpalo, Kati, [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-06-14/nokia-apple-payments-to-nokia-settle-all-litigation.html Nokia Wins Apple Patent-License Deal Cash, Settles Lawsuits], Bloomberg News, bloomberg.com, June 14, 2011. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref>
====''Apple v. HTC''==== Apple filed a patent infringement suit against [[HTC|High Tech Computer Corp.]] (HTC) in March 2010 in the [[United States District Court for the District of Delaware|U.S. District Court for the District of Delaware]]<ref name="appleHTC">''[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=12312555522065197626 Apple v. HTC]'', C.A. Nos. 10-166-GMS, 10-167-GMS, U.S. Dist. Ct., D. Del., January 14, 2011. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref> in the two companies' ongoing battle with each other,<ref name="chengHAagain">Cheng, Roger, [http://news.cnet.com/8301-1035_3-20092936-94/htc-sues-apple-again/ HTC sues Apple, again], CNET News, news.cnet.com, August 16, 2011. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref> and a complaint against HTC under Section 337 of the [[Smoot–Hawley Tariff Act|Tariff Act of 1930]] with the [[U.S. International Trade Commission]] (ITC) in Washington, D.C.<ref name="appleHTCatITC">Apple's ITC complaint against HTC, 75 Fed. Reg. 17434, April 6, 2010.</ref><ref name="Patel">Patel, Nilay, [https://www.engadget.com/2010/03/02/apple-vs-htc-a-patent-breakdown/ Apple vs HTC: a patent breakdown], Engaget, engadget.com, March 2, 2010. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref> Apple's suit alleged 20 separate patent infringements relating to the iPhone's user interface, underlying architecture and hardware.<ref name="Bilton">Bilton, Nick, [http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/03/02/what-apple-vs-htc-could-mean/ What Apple vs. HTC Could Mean], Bits, ''The New York Times'', bits.blogs.nytimes.com, March 2, 2010. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref> Steve Jobs exclaimed "We can sit by and watch competitors steal our patented inventions, or we can do something about it. We've decided to do something about it ... [We] think competition is healthy, but competitors should create their own original technology, not steal ours".<ref name="Foresman">Foresman, Chris, [https://arstechnica.com/apple/2010/03/apple-vs-htc-a-proxy-fight-over-android-could-last-years/ Apple vs HTC: proxy fight over Android could last years], Ars Technica, arstechnica.com, March 4, 2010. Accessed July 22, 2012.</ref> The ITC rejected all but one of Apple's claims, however, ruling for Apple on a single claim relating to data tapping.<ref name="itcAppleHTCofficial">ITC, ''In The Matter of Certain Personal Data and Mobile Communications Devices and Related Software'', Notice of the Commission's Final Determination Finding a Violation Of Section 337, [http://www.usitc.gov/secretary/fed_reg_notices/337/337_710_Notice12192011sgl.pdf Issuance of a Limited Exclusion Order, Termination of Investigation No. 337-Ta-710] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120130233318/http://usitc.gov/secretary/fed_reg_notices/337/337_710_Notice12192011sgl.pdf |date=January 30, 2012 }}, usitc.gov, December 19, 2011. Accessed 2012-7-27. See also [https://www.google.com/patents/US5946647 Apple's patent No. 5,946,647] at google.com. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref><ref name="declanLooming">McCullagh, Declan, [http://news.cnet.com/8301-13579_3-57345291-37/apple-wins-patent-victory-over-htc-which-faces-looming-import-ban/ Apple wins patent victory over HTC, which faces looming import ban], CNET News, news.cnet.com, December 19, 2011. Accessed 2012-7-22.</ref> HTC motioned the Delaware court for a [[Venue (law)|change of venue]] to the Northern District of California, arguing against Apple's desire to consolidate the case with the similar cases brought by Nokia against Apple,<ref name="htcNokiaMotion">''Nokia Corporation v. Apple Inc.'', case 09-791 and ''Nokia Corporation v. Apple Inc.'', case 09-1002, both U.S. Dist.Ct., ND Cal. 2011.</ref> alleging insubstantial overlap between those cases and Apple's complaint, but Judge [[Gregory M. Sleet]] denied HTC's motion for a venue change, ruling that Apple's choice of forum would prevail.<ref name="appleHTC" /> HTC countersued Apple in September 2011 in the same court claiming infringement of four patents HTC obtained from [[Google]],<ref name="htcBloomberg">Milford, Phil and Decker, Susan, [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-09-07/htc-sues-apple-alleging-infringement-of-four-u-s-patents.html HTC Sues Apple Using Google Patents Bought Last Week as Battle Escalates], Bloomberg News, bloomberg.com, September 7, 2011. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref> also filing a counter-complaint with the ITC, with HTC's general counsel saying "HTC will continue to protect its patented inventions against infringement from Apple until such infringement stops."<ref name="htcBloomberg" /><ref name="htcCounterApple">Cheng, Roger, [http://news.cnet.com/8301-1035_3-20102903-94/htc-sues-apple-using-google-patents-report-says/ HTC sues Apple using Google patents, report says], CNET News, news.cnet.com, September 7, 2011. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref> In May 2012 the Delaware court ordered mediation between the companies.<ref>Levine, Dan, [https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/05/20/us-apple-samsung-court-idUSBRE84J06X20120520 Apple, Samsung CEOs set for court talks], Reuters, reuters.com, May 20, 2012. Accessed 2012-7-25.</ref> In November 2012, HTC and Apple ended the patent dispute by settling the case, but did not disclose the terms of the settlement. The companies reported the settlement included a 10-year agreement for licensing both companies' current and future patents to each other."<ref name="apphtcSettle">Mullin, Joe, [https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2012/11/apple-and-htc-reach-patent-peace-but-at-what-cost/ Apple and HTC reach a sudden patent peace, but at what cost?], ArsTechnica, arstechnica.com, November 11, 2012. Accessed 2012-12-21.</ref>
====''Kodak v. Apple'' (digital imaging)==== [[Eastman Kodak]] sued Apple and [[Research In Motion]] (RIM) in January 2010, filing two lawsuits against Apple and a complaint with the U.S. International Trade Commission against both Apple and RIM after the companies refused to pay royalties for use of Kodak's patents for digital cameras. Kodak alleged Apple's and RIM's phones infringed on patented Kodak [[digital imaging]] technology.<ref>''Eastman Kodak Company v. Apple Inc.'', case 6:2010cv06022, U.S. Dist.Ct., WD NY (Rochester), filed January 14, 2010.</ref><ref>Lloyd, Mary Ellen, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704281204575002891721364642 Kodak Sues Apple, RIM Over Patents], ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', online.wsj.com, January 14, 2010. Accessed 2010-7-27.</ref> Kodak sought an injunction against further imports into the United States of Apple's iPhone and RIM's [[BlackBerry]].<ref>Decker, Susan, [https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=a3MJ_mLGMdI8 Apple, RIM Accused of Infringing Kodak Patents (Update4)], Bloomberg News, bloomberg.com, January 14, 2010. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref> After Kodak filed an additional suit in January 2012 against Apple and another against HTC claiming infringement of four of its key patents, Apple filed a countersuit with the [[United States bankruptcy court|U.S. Bankruptcy Court]] to block Kodak's efforts to use the disputed patents as collateral for loans.<ref>Mandalia, Ravi, [http://www.itproportal.com/2012/01/24/apple-counters-kodaks-patent-ownership-claims/ Apple Counters Kodak's Patent Ownership Claims], ITProPortal, itproportal.com, January 24, 2012. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref> In the January complaint Kodak claimed violations of the same image preview technology at issue in the original dispute between Kodak, Apple, and RIM that is, as of 2012, pending before ITC.<ref>Mandalia, Ravi, [http://www.itproportal.com/2012/01/12/kodak-files-patent-infringement-lawsuits-against-apple-htc/ Kodak Files Patent Infringement Lawsuits Against Apple, HTC], ITProPortal, itproportal.com, January 12, 2012. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref> In March 2012, [[bankruptcy]] court judge [[List of judges of the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York|Allen Gropper]], overseeing Kodak's restructuring, denied Apple's request to file a patent complaint with the ITC over some of Kodak's cameras, photo frames, and printers.<ref>patentadmin, [http://www.generalpatent.com/apple-denied-permission-file-patent-infringement-suit-against-bankrupt-kodak Apple Denied Permission to File Patent Infringement Suit Against Bankrupt Kodak], General Patent Corporation, generalpatent.com, March 9, 2012. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref> In July 2012, the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit|Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit]] ruled that Kodak did not infringe on Apple's patent technology for digital cameras, although a few days earlier Kodak lost its case before the ITC against Apple and RIM; Kodak announced it would appeal that decision.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/07/23/kodak-apple-patent-idUSL2E8IN9L320120723 Appeals court says Kodak does not infringe Apple patent], Reuters, reuters.com, July 23, 2012. Accessed 2012-7-25.</ref>
====''Motorola Mobility v. Apple''==== {{main|Motorola Mobility v. Apple Inc.}}
In the year before Apple and Samsung began suing each other on most continents, and while Apple and HTC were already embroiled in a patent fight, [[Motorola Mobility]] and Apple started a period of intense patent litigation. The Motorola-Apple patent imbroglio commenced with claims and cross-claims between the companies for patent infringement and encompassed multiple forums in multiple countries as each party sought friendly venues for litigating its respective claims; the fight also included [[administrative law]] rulings as well as ITC and [[European Commission]] involvement.<ref>The cases include: ''Motorola Mobility, Inc. v. Apple Inc.'', ''In the Matter of Certain Wireless Communication Devices, Portable Music and Data Processing Devices, Computers and Components Thereof'', ITC Inv. No. 337-TA-745, October 6, 2010; ''Motorola Mobility, Inc. v. Apple Inc. and NeXT Software, Inc.'', U.S. Dist. Ct., Dist. Del., October 8, 2010; ''Apple Inc. v. Motorola, Inc. and Motorola Mobility, Inc.'', U.S. Dist. Ct., W.Dist. Wisc., 2010-10-29; ''In the Matter of Certain Mobile Devices and Related Software'', ITC Inv. No. 337-TA-750, 2010-10-29; ''Apple v. Motorola'', 337-TA-750, 2012-3-16; ''Apple, Inc. and Apple Sales International v. Motorola Mobility, Inc.'', case 12CV0355 JLS BLM, U.S. Dist. Ct., S.D. Cal., 2012-2-10.</ref> As of April 2012, the controversy centered on whether a [[reasonable and non-discriminatory licensing|FRAND]] license to a components manufacturer carries over to an equipment manufacturer incorporating the component into equipment, an issue not addressed in the U.S. Supreme Court's default [[exhaustion doctrine]] in ''[[Quanta Computer, Inc. v. LG Electronics, Inc.|Quanta v. LG Electronics]]''.<ref name="skullduggery">Stern, Richard, [http://ipv6.ppk.itb.ac.id/~dikshie/IEEE-Micro/06177305.pdf Standardization Skullduggery Never Ends: Apple v. Motorola] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120417001234/http://ipv6.ppk.itb.ac.id/~dikshie/IEEE-Micro/06177305.pdf |date=April 17, 2012 }}, IEEE Micro, ipv6.ppk.itb.ac.id, 2012-3/4, <nowiki>[3B2-9] mmi2012020003.3d 10/3/012 16:48</nowiki> p. 3. Accessed 2012-4-13. Stern cites ''[https://archive.is/20130124174515/http://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=13486316684325795728 Quanta Computer, Inc. v. LG Electronics, Inc.]'', 128 S. Ct. 2109, 2008; accessed 2012-4-13. The ''Quanta'' case cited the 150-year-old doctrine of patent exhaustion which limits patent rights that survive the initial authorized sale of a patented item.</ref> In June 2012, appellate Judge [[Richard Posner]] ordered dismissal of the case [[Prejudice (legal procedure)|with prejudice]] and Apple announced its intention to appeal a month later.<ref>Mueller, Florian, [http://www.fosspatents.com/2012/07/apple-and-google-subsidiary-motorola.html Apple and Google subsidiary Motorola Mobility both appeal Judge Posner's ruling], FOSS Patents, fosspatents.com, July 21, 2012. Accessed 2012-7-25.</ref><ref>Levine, Dan [https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/07/05/us-apple-google-judge-idUSBRE8640IQ20120705 Judge who shelved Apple trial says patent system out of sync], Reuters, reuters.com, July 5, 2012. Accessed July 25, 2012.</ref>
====''Apple v. Samsung'': Android phones and tablets==== {{main|Apple Inc. v. Samsung Electronics Co., Ltd.}} ''Apple Inc. v. Samsung Electronics Co., Ltd.'' was the first of many lawsuits between Apple and Samsung. In the spring of 2011, Apple sued Samsung while already fully engaged in a [[patent war]] with Motorola.<ref>''[http://cand.uscourts.gov/lhk/applevsamsung Apple Inc. v. Samsung Electronics Co., Ltd.]'', case 11-CV-01846-LHK, 768 F. Supp. 2d 1040, U.S. Dist. Ct., N.D.Cal. 2011-4. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref> Apple's multinational litigation over technology patents became known as the [[mobile device]] patent wars:<ref>Barrett, Paul M., [http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2012-03-29/apple-s-war-on-android Apple's War on Android], Bloomberg Businessweek, businessweek.com, March 29, 2012. Accessed 2012-7-25.</ref> Extensive litigation followed fierce competition in the global market for consumer mobile communications.
By August 2011, Apple and Samsung were engaged in 19 ongoing lawsuits in 12 courts in nine countries on four continents; by October, the fight expanded to 10 countries,<ref name="Albanesius">Albanesius, Chloe, [https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2392920,00.asp Every Place Samsung and Apple Are Suing Each Other], ''[[PC Magazine]]'', pcmag.com, September 14, 2011. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref><ref name="ssOzAppeal">[https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/10/27/us-apple-samsung-australia-idUSTRE79Q0SN20111027 Australian court to fast-track Samsung appeal on tablet ban], Reuters, reuters.com, October 27, 2011. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref> and by July 2012, the two companies were embroiled in more than 50 lawsuits around the globe with billions of dollars in damages claimed between them.<ref>Mueller, Florian, [http://www.fosspatents.com/2012/07/apple-seeks-25-billion-in-damages-from.html Apple seeks .5 billion in damages from Samsung, offers half a cent per standard-essential patent], FOSS Patents, fosspatents.com, July 24, 2012. Accessed 2012-7-28.</ref> As of August 2013, the ultimate cost of these patent wars to consumers, shareholders, and investors is not known.<ref name="ipocracy">Hintjens, Pieter, [http://www.ipocracy.org/article:1#toc10 Patents Considered Evil: The Rational for Patents] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222130154/http://www.ipocracy.org/article:1#toc10#toc10 |date=February 22, 2012 }}, IPocracy, ipocracy.org, 2011-9. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref><ref name="mohan">Mohan, Ravi, [http://www.chtlj.org/sites/default/files/media/articles/v027/v027.i3.Mohan_.pdf Analysis Of The Entire Market Value Rule In Complex Technology Litigation: Arduous Royalty Base Determinations, Unjust Damage Rewards, And Empirical Approaches To Measuring Consumer Demand] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120711011443/http://www.chtlj.org/sites/default/files/media/articles/v027/v027.i3.Mohan_.pdf |date=July 11, 2012 }}, Santa Clara ''Computer & High Technology Law Journal'', chtlj.org, vol. 27, 2011-4, pp. 637–671 at 639. Accessed July 27, 2012. See also * Mack, Eric, [http://www.pcworld.com/article/239873/mobile_patent_wars_a_closer_look_at_how_everyone_loses.html#tk.mod_stln Mobile Patent Wars: A Closer Look at How Everyone Loses], PCWorld, pcworld.com, November 6, 2011. Accessed 2012-8-3. * Masnick, Mike, [http://www.techdirt.com/blog/innovation/articles/20120320/04033218169/just-because-companies-can-design-around-patents-doesnt-mean-theres-no-impact-consumers.shtml Just Because Companies Can Design Around Patents Doesn't Mean There's No Impact For Consumers], [[Techdirt]], techdirt.com, 2012-3-20. Accessed 2012-7-27; and * Allison, John, Lemley, Mark, Moore, Kimberly, and Trunkey, R. Derek, Valuable Patents, ''Geo. Law Journal'', v. 92, pp. 435, 441, 2004, in which the authors noted "Total direct litigation costs for the median patent case with between $1 million and $25 million at stake were $2 million per side in 2003."</ref>
A U.S. jury trial was held on July 30, 2012, with Apple prevailing and Samsung ordered to pay more than $1 billion in damages,<ref name="appSamDecision">''[http://cand.uscourts.gov/lhk/applevsamsung Apple Inc. v. Samsung Electronics Co., Ltd.]'', case 11-CV-01846-LHK, 768 F. Supp. 2d 1040, U.S. Dist. Ct., N.D.Cal. 2011-4. Accessed July 25, 2012.</ref><ref name="huffVerdictRpt">[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/08/24/apple-vs-samsung-verdict_n_1829119.html Apple vs. Samsung Verdict Is In After Epic Patent Trial (UPDATES)], ''The Huffington Post'', huffingtonpost.com, August 24, 2012. Accessed 2012-12-21.</ref> after which Samsung stated: "This is not the final word in this case or in battles being waged in courts and tribunals around the world, some of which have already rejected many of Apple's claims."<ref name="samsungNotFinal">[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/08/24/samsung-apple-not-final-word_n_1829356.html Samsung: Apple Victory 'Not Final Word'], ''Reuters'' via ''The Huffington Post'', huffingtonpost.com, August 24, 2012. Accessed 2012-12-21.</ref> Judge [[Lucy H. Koh]] later decided that the jury had miscalculated $450 million in its initial damage assessment and ordered a retrial that commenced in November 2013.<ref name="Art" /> Following a week-long trial, also overseen by Judge Koh, Samsung was ordered to pay $600 million to Apple for the 2012 lawsuit.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jury tells Samsung to pay up, awards Apple $290 million in damages [updated]|url=http://bgr.com/2013/11/21/apple-samsung-patent-trial-verdict/|work=BGR|publisher=BGR Media, LLC|accessdate=7 April 2014|author=Brad Reed|date=21 November 2013}}</ref>
On August 9, 2013, the U.S. International Trade Commission (USITC) announced its decision regarding an Apple-initiated case, whereby Samsung is accused of infringing four Apple patents related to user interfaces and headphone input functionality.<ref name="Gross">{{cite web|title=Movement expected Friday in Apple, Samsung patent wars|url=http://www.macworld.com/article/2046201/apple-and-samsung-patent-war-returns-friday.html|work=MacWorld|publisher=IDG Consumer & SMB|accessdate=August 9, 2013|author=Grant Gross|date=August 8, 2013}}</ref> The USITC sided with Apple in what was described in the media as a "mixed ruling" and stated that some of Samsung's older devices infringe on two of Apple's patents—one covering touch-screen technology and another regarding headphone jacks; however, no violations were identified in four other patents. The final determination of the ITC was signed by Lisa Barton, Acting Secretary to the Commission.<ref>{{cite web|title=Apple wins U.S. ban on older Samsung devices in mixed ruling|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13579_3-57597856-37/apple-wins-u.s-ban-on-older-samsung-devices-in-mixed-ruling/|work=Cnet|publisher=CBS Interactive Inc|accessdate=15 November 2013|author=Josh Lowensohn|date=9 August 2013}}</ref>
In a damage-only retrial court session on November 13, 2013, as ordered by Judge Koh in December 2012, a Samsung Electronics representative stated in a San Jose, U.S. courtroom that Apple's hometown jury found that the company copied some features of both the iPhone and iPad. Samsung's attorney clarified the purpose of the damage-only retrial and stated the result of the first trial, "This is a case not where we're disputing that the 13 phones contain some elements of Apple's property," but the company has disputed the $379.8 million amount that Apple claimed — Samsung presented a figure of $52 million.<ref name="Art">{{cite news|title=Samsung says $52m, not $380m, is owed for Apple patent infringement|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2013/nov/14/samsung-patent-infringement-apple-owes?CMP=EMCNEWEML6619I2|accessdate=15 November 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=14 November 2013|author=Charles Arthur}}</ref> The San Jose jury eventually awarded Apple $290 million in damages after jurors completed a one-page assessment form for each infringed patent. The six-woman, two-man jury reached its decision after a three-day period.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jury Tells Samsung to Pay Apple $290 Million|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/22/technology/jury-finds-samsung-owes-290-million-in-apple-patent-trial.html?_r=0|accessdate=7 April 2014|newspaper=The New York Times|date=21 November 2013|author=Brian X. Chen}}</ref>
In the first week of January 2014, a filing with the U.S. District court in San Jose showed that legal executives from both parties agreed to meet prior to February 19, 2014, to engage in settlement discussions. Both Samsung and Apple were responding to a court order that instructed the completion of such a meeting before a new trial begins in March 2014. One of three Samsung chiefs met with Cook, but the filing did not reveal the name of the representative.<ref>{{cite news|title=Samsung, Apple CEOs To Discuss Lawsuit Settlement|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/01/09/apple-samsung-settlement_n_4567217.html|accessdate=7 April 2014|newspaper=The Huffington Post|date=9 January 2014|author=Youkyung Lee}}</ref>
A new trial is scheduled for March 2014, in which Apple will seek to prevent Samsung from selling some of its current devices in the U.S. The case will involve further debate over monetary compensation.<ref name="Art" /> In the 2014 lawsuit, Samsung is accused of infringing five of Apple Inc.'s patents in 10 phone and tablet models, while Samsung has responded with a counterclaim, in which it states that two patents for nine phones and tablets have been infringed on by Apple. Jury selection for the trial occurred on March 31, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=Apple, Samsung kick off case by sparring over instructional video|url=http://www.macworld.com/article/2137760/judge-overrules-samsung-objection-to-jury-video-depicting-apple-devices.html#tk.nl_mwbest|work=Macworld|publisher=IDG Consumer & SMB|accessdate=7 April 2014|author=John Ribeiro|date=31 January 2014}}</ref> Samsung stands to gain $6 million if the jury rules in its favor, while Apple is seeking $2 billion in damages and could proceed with similar lawsuits against other Android handset makers, as the relevant patent issues extend beyond Samsung's software technology.<ref name="New">{{cite news|title=Apple sues Samsung for $2bn as tech rivals head back to court|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/mar/31/apple-sues-samsung-for-2bn?INTCMP=ILCNETTXT3487|accessdate=7 April 2014|newspaper=The Guardian|date=31 March 2014}}</ref>
====''Corephotonics v. Apple''==== On 6 November 2017, [[Israel]]i [[Startup company|start-up]] Corephotonics sued Apple. They claimed that the technology behind the dual-camera systems in Apple's [[iPhone 7|iPhone 7 Plus]] and [[iPhone 8|8 Plus]] infringed four patents owned by them (Corephotonics). Corephotonics said that they approached Apple over a possible partnership, but Apple's lead negotiator apparently declined the idea, with Apple going ahead and launching the iPhone 7 Plus in late 2016, and then the 8 Plus in late 2017.
{{quote|Apple's lead negotiator expressed contempt for Corephotonics' patents, telling Dr. Mendlovic and others that even if Apple infringed, it would take years and millions of dollars in litigation before Apple might have to pay something.|source=Corephotonics LTD.}}
The patents claimed by Corephotonics to be infringed are: two patents on mini telephoto lens assembly, one patent on dual aperture zoom digital cameras, and one on high resolution thin multi-aperture imaging systems.
Corephotonics also blamed Apple's consumers (who bought the 7 Plus or 8 Plus) to be infringing the patents, as they claim that Apple sells the products with "knowledge of or willful blindness", which the consumers buy.
The lawsuit demands monetary compensation for the lawyers the start-up had to hire, as well as for damages. They are also asking Apple to immediately stop producing dual-lens cameras systems. The [[iPhone X]] is not included in the lawsuit, despite having a dual-lens camera.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/11/7/16619138/apple-israel-dual-lens-iphone-7-8-plus-patent-lawsuit|title=Israeli company sues Apple for dual lens camera patent infringement|work=The Verge|access-date=2017-11-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.macrumors.com/2017/11/07/corephotonics-vs-apple/|title=Corephotonics Sues Apple Over Dual-Lens Cameras in iPhone 7 Plus and iPhone 8 Plus|access-date=2017-11-08|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-apple-patents-lawsuit/israeli-start-up-says-apple-copied-its-patented-smartphone-camera-technology-idUSKBN1D72M0|title=Israeli start-up says Apple copied its patented smartphone camera technology|date=2017-11-07|work=Reuters|access-date=2017-11-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.engadget.com/2017/11/07/israeli-company-claims-apple-copied-its-dual-camera-tech/|title=Israeli company claims Apple copied its dual-camera tech|work=Engadget|access-date=2017-11-08|language=en-US}}</ref>
===Licensing===
====Norwegian Consumer Council====
In June 2006, the Consumer [[Ombudsman|Ombudsmen]] in [[Norway]], [[Sweden]] and [[Denmark]] challenged Apple's iTunes [[end user license agreement]] (EULA) through the Norwegian Consumer Ombudsman Bjørn Erik Thon, who claimed that Apple was violating contract and copyright laws in their countries. Thon stated that Apple's "being an international company does not entitle <nowiki>[it]</nowiki> to disregard the laws of the countries in which it operates. The company's standard customer contract violates Norwegian law".<ref name="violatesNorwayLaw">[http://www.forbrukerombudet.no/id/11032467.0 iTunes violates Norwegian law] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206125947/http://www.forbrukerombudet.no/id/11032467.0 |date=February 6, 2012 }}, Forbrukerombudet Norway, forbrukerombudet.no, June 7, 2006. Accessed July 22, 2012.</ref> An official complaint<ref>{{cite web|url=http://forbrukerportalen.no/filearchive/Complaint%20against%20iTunes%20Music%20Store.pdf |title=Norwegian EULA complaint |accessdate=2012-04-01 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060613185025/http://forbrukerportalen.no/filearchive/Complaint%20against%20iTunes%20Music%20Store.pdf |archivedate=June 13, 2006 |df=mdy }}, Norwegian Consumer Council web service forbrukerportalen.no (via archive.org), 2006. Accessed July 22, 2012.</ref> was filed by the [[Norwegian Consumer Council]] in January 2006,<ref>Singstad, Jo,{{cite web|url=http://forbrukerportalen.no/Artikler/2006/1138119849.71 |title=iTunes' questionable terms and conditions – Forbrukerportalen |accessdate=2013-09-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720185711/http://forbrukerportalen.no/Artikler/2006/1138119849.71 |archivedate=July 20, 2011 |df=mdy }}, Norwegian Consumer Council (via archive.org), January 25, 2006. Accessed 2012-7-22.</ref> after which German and French consumer groups joined the Nordic-led drive to force Apple to make its iTunes online store compatible with digital music players made by rival companies.<ref name="cnnNorwayComplaint">{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/TECH/internet/01/23/europe.itunes.ap/index.html |title=European drive against iTunes builds support |accessdate=2007-02-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070202031619/http://www.cnn.com/2007/TECH/internet/01/23/europe.itunes.ap/index.html |archivedate=February 2, 2007 |df=mdy }}, CNN, January 23, 2007. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref> A French law allows regulators to force Apple to make its player and store compatible with rival offerings.<ref name="cnnNorwayComplaint" /> The consumer protection regulators of Norway, Sweden, and Finland met with Apple in September 2006 in hopes of resolving the issues without litigation,<ref>Oates, John, [https://www.theregister.co.uk/2006/09/29/apple_norway_row/ Apple's talks with Nordic regulators positive], ''The Register'', theregister.co.uk, September 29, 2006. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref> but the matter was only resolved after Apple discontinued its [[FairPlay]] [[digital rights management]] (DRM) scheme.<ref>Cheng, Jacqui, [https://arstechnica.com/apple/2009/02/norway-we-have-no-reason-to-pursue-apple-over-drm-anymore/ Norway: no reason to hound Apple over DRM any longer], Ars Technica, arstechnica.com, February 4, 2009. Accessed July 22, 2012.</ref>
====Office of Fair Trading investigation====
In 2008, the UK [[Consumer Focus|National Consumer Council]] (NCC, now Consumer Focus) called on the UK's [[Office of Fair Trading]] (OFT) to investigate Apple's EULA, claiming Apple's EULA, and those of multiple other technology companies, misled consumers and infringed legal rights. The NCC's product complaint included Apple's [[iLife]] as well as Microsoft's [[Microsoft Office|Office for Mac]], and products by [[Corel]], [[Adobe Systems|Adobe]], [[Symantec]], [[Kaspersky Lab|Kaspersky]], [[McAfee]], and others.<ref>Oates, John, [https://www.theregister.co.uk/2008/02/19/eulas_unfair_investigation/ Consumer group slams 'unfair' software licenses, EULAugh, I cry], ''The Register'', theregister.co.uk, February 19, 2008. Accessed 2012-7-25.</ref> The OFT determined the licensing agreements were unfair and Apple agreed to improve its terms and conditions to make them clearer and fairer to consumers.<ref>[http://www.oft.gov.uk/news-and-updates/press/2009/136-09 Apple agrees to improve terms and conditions] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100524101212/http://www.oft.gov.uk/news-and-updates/press/2009/136-09 |date=May 24, 2010 }}, U.K. Office of Fair Trading, oft.gov.uk, 136/09, November 27, 2009. Accessed 2012-7-25.</ref>
====''Apple Inc. v. Psystar Corporation''==== In July 2008, Apple Inc. filed suit against [[Psystar Corporation]]<ref name="appleVsPystar">''[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?q=Apple+Inc.+v.+Psystar+Corp&hl=en&as_sdt=2,48&as_vis=1&case=1322564748830727512&scilh=0 Apple Inc. v. Psystar Corporation]'', 673 F. Supp. 2d 943, U.S. Dist.Ct., N.D. Cal. 2009. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref> alleging Psystar sold [[Intel]]-based systems with [[macOS|Mac OS X]] pre-installed and that, in so doing, violated Apple's copyright and trademark rights and the [[software license|software licensing]] terms of Apple's [[Shrink wrap contract|shrink wrap license]]. That [[license]] restricted the use of Mac OS X to Apple computers, and specifically prohibited customers from installing the operating system on non-Apple computers.The case brought the anti-circumvention and anti-trafficking facets of the [[DMCA]] into this licensing dispute, with Apple ultimately prevailing and awarded permanent injunctive relief, and the decision affirmed on appeal in 2011.<ref name="psystarAppeal">''[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?q=Apple+Inc.+v.+Psystar+Corp&hl=en&as_sdt=2,48&as_vis=1&case=115813569563137915&scilh=0 Apple Inc. v. Psystar Corporation]'', case 10-15113, U.S. Ct.App., 9th Cir. 2011. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref> Psystar's appeal asserted copyright misuse as a defense by arguing that Apple's license agreement was an unlawful attempt to extend copyright protection to products that are not copyrightable. The appeals court ruled that Psystar failed to demonstrate "copyright misuse" by Apple because Psystar must show either that the license agreement restricts creativity or that it restricts competition, and that Apple's [[license]] agreement does neither.<ref>http://cdn.ca9.uscourts.gov/datastore/opinions/2011/09/28/10-15113.pdf</ref> <!-- leave extra lines -->
==Corporate espionage and data theft==
=== QuickTime code theft litigation === {{main|San Francisco Canyon Company}} In 1995, Apple added Microsoft and Intel to an existing lawsuit against the [[San Francisco Canyon Company]], alleging that Microsoft and Intel knowingly used the software company to aid them in stealing several thousand lines of Apple's [[QuickTime]] code in an effort to improve the performance of [[Video for Windows]].<ref>Markoff, John, [https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/10/business/company-news-intel-and-microsoft-added-to-apple-lawsuit.html Intel and Microsoft Added to Apple Lawsuit], ''The New York Times'', nytimes.com, February 10, 1995. Accessed 2012-7-22. *Duncan, Geoff,{{cite web |url=http://www.tidbits.com/tb-issues/TidBITS-263.html#lnk3 |title=Apple Sues Intel, Microsoft – Again |accessdate=2007-02-01 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19970410094224/http://www.tidbits.com/tb-issues/TidBITS-263.html#lnk3 |archivedate=April 10, 1997 |df=mdy }}, TidBITS, 1995-2-13. Accessed 2012-7-22. *Mace, Michael, {{cite web |url=http://www.pa.msu.edu/~hamlin/facts/1stltr.html |title=An Open Letter to the Computing Community |accessdate=2001-06-05 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010605082836/http://www.pa.msu.edu/~hamlin/facts/1stltr.html |archivedate=June 5, 2001 |df= }}, pa.msu.edu, February 9, 1995. Accessed 2012-7-27. *Mace, Michael,{{cite web |url=http://www.pa.msu.edu/~hamlin/facts/2ndltr.html |title=Second open letter from Apple |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20001012140945/http://www.pa.msu.edu/~hamlin/facts/2ndltr.html |archivedate=October 12, 2000 }}, pa.msu.edu. Accessed 2012-7-27.</ref> After a threat to withdraw support for the Macintosh edition of Microsoft Office<ref>Graham, Lea, [https://www.theregister.co.uk/1999/02/01/maritz_on_apple/ Maritz on... Apple], ''The Register'', theregister.co.uk, February 1, 1999. Accessed July 27, 2012.</ref><ref>Chalmers, Rachel, [http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0CGN/is_1999_Jan_26/ai_53999515 Apple And Microsoft: Jobs Barefoot Under A Tree], ''Computergram International'' (via findarticles.com), January 26, 1999. Accessed 2012-7-22.</ref> the suit was settled in 1997, along with all lingering issues from the ''[[#Apple v. Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard|Apple Computer, Inc. v. Microsoft Corporation]]'' "look & feel" suit. Apple agreed to make [[Internet Explorer]] the default browser over [[Netscape]], while Microsoft agreed to continue developing Office and other software for the Mac for the next five years and to purchase $150 million of non-voting Apple stock.<ref name="applemscnet" /><ref name="applemsfindlaw" />
===FBI demand to unlock iPhone=== {{main|FBI–Apple encryption dispute}} In February 2016, the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]], as part of its investigation into the [[2015 San Bernardino attack]], obtained a court order that demanded that Apple create a version of its operating system that would allow the FBI to circumvent security controls, so that it could inspect the contents of an iPhone used by [[Rizwan Farook and Tashfeen Malik#Rizwan Farook|one of the terrorists]] involved in the attack. Apple claimed the order "would undermine the very freedoms and liberty our government is meant to protect" and appealed.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.inc.com/joseph-steinberg/why-apple-is-fighting-the-fbi-and-what-it-means-to-you.html | title=Why Apple Is Fighting the FBI--and What It Means to You |author=Joseph Steinberg |authorlink=Joseph Steinberg | publisher=Inc. | date=17 February 2016 | accessdate=18 February 2016}}</ref> On March 28, 2016, the DOJ reported that it had retrieved the data from the attacker's iPhone through an alternative method without Apple's assistance, ending the legal proceedings.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/3/28/11317396/apple-fbi-encryption-vacate-iphone-order-san-bernardino|title=Apple's San Bernardino fight is officially over as government confirms working attack|website=The Verge|access-date=2016-03-30}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Smartphone patent wars]] * [[Batterygate]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[https://www.apple.com/legal/ Apple Legal]
{{Apple}}

Litigation}} [[Category:Apple Inc. litigation|*]] [[Category:Lawsuits]] [[Category:United States lawsuits|*]] [[Category:Class action lawsuits]] [[Category:Conflict of laws case law]] [[Category:Defamation case law]] [[Category:Intellectual property case law]] [[Category:Patent case law]] [[Category:United States case law lists]] [[Category:United States administrative case law]] [[Category:United States antitrust case law]] [[Category:United States computer case law]] [[Category:United States contract case law]] [[Category:United States copyright case law]] [[Category:United States defamation case law]] [[Category:United States Internet case law]] [[Category:United States patent case law]] [[Category:United States trademark case law]] [[Category:Ongoing legal cases]] [[Category:United States district court cases]] [[Category:Litigation by party]]

{{notability|date=December 2017}}{{more citations needed|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox book | name = Arab Encyclopedia
الموسوعة العربية | image = | author = | language = [[Arabic]] | country = [[Syria]] | genre = [[Encyclopedia]] | alt = الموسوعة العربية | series = 24 volumes | pub_date = 1998 - First Edition {{cite web|title=first edition|url=http://www.albayan.ae/five-senses/1999-09-11-1.1032808}} }} '''Arab Encyclopedia''' (Arabic: الموسوعة العربية){{Cite web|url=http://www.arab-ency.com/_/|title=الموسوعة العربية|last=Encyclopedia|first=Arab|date=|website=www.arab-ency.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-12-25}} is an encyclopedia in 24 volumes in the Arabic language. In 1953, [[Syria]] proposed the project to the [[Arab League]] who adopted a resolution to set up "The Arab Encyclopedia".Institution Of The Arab Encyclopedia. '''Middle East News Online; Durham''' [Durham] 05 Dec 2000 Another proposal for an "Arab Encyclopedia" was submitted to the Arab League in 1961.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=gQ_WCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA367&dq=%22arab+encyclopedia%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiOsMu_lqbYAhWiCsAKHUaIBc4Q6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=%22arab%20encyclopedia%22&f=false|title=The League of Arab States: A Study in Dynamics of Regional Organization|last=MacDonald|first=Robert W.|date=2015-12-08|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn=9781400875283|language=en}} However, the project was not implemented for unidentified reason. Syria adopted a resolution to establish the 'Institute of the Arab Encyclopedia' (IAE) ({{Lang-ar|هيئة الموسوعة العربية}}) in 1981 which issued the first edition of the encyclopedia in 1998 in Damascus, Syria. In 2016, the official website was launched which allows free access to all the entries of the encyclopedia. == References == [[Category:Arabic-language encyclopedias]] [[Category:Online encyclopedias]] [[Category:Arab encyclopedias]] [[Category:20th-century encyclopedias]] [[Category:21st-century encyclopedias]] [[Category:1998 books]] {{encyclopedia-stub}}

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Bulfinch's Mythology''''' is a collection of [[general audience]] works by American [[Latinist]] and banker [[Thomas Bulfinch]], named after him and published after his death in 1867. The work was a highly successful popularization of [[Greek mythology]] for English-speaking readers. Carl J. Richard comments that it was "one of the most popular books ever published in the United States and the standard work on [[classical mythology]] for nearly a century," until the release of classicist [[Edith Hamilton]]'s 1942 ''[[Mythology (book)|Mythology: Timeless Tales of Gods and Heroes]]''.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=0qAY29cYNxsC&pg=PA33&dq=bulfinch’s+mythology+by+thomas+bulfinch&hl=en&ei=Ew9fTYqwB8iCgAfYmuWKDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CFQQ6AEwCDgU#v=onepage&q=bulfinch’s%20mythology%20by%20thomas%20bulfinch&f=false Richard, Carl J., ''The Golden Age of the Classics in America,''] Harvard University Press, 2009, page 33.</ref>
The book is a prose recounting of [[myth]]s and stories from three eras: Greek and [[Roman mythology]], [[King Arthur]] legends and [[chivalric romance|medieval romances]]. Bulfinch intersperses the stories with his own commentary, and with quotations from writings by his contemporaries that refer to the story under discussion. This combination of classical elements and modern literature was novel for his time.<ref name="Miscuit">[https://web.archive.org/web/20060720010620/http://www.fivecolleges.edu/mcleary/cl-world.html Miscuit utile dulci: ''Bulfinch's Mythology'' as a pedagogical prototype] ''Classical World'', Vol. 78, No. 6 (1985), page 591, accessed 19 August 2015 via Wayback Machine</ref>
Bulfinch expressly intended his work for the general reader. In the preface to ''The Age of Fable'' he states "Our work is not for the learned, nor for the theologian, nor for the philosopher, but for the reader of English literature, of either sex, who wishes to comprehend the allusions so frequently made by public speakers, lecturers, essayists, and poets, and those which occur in polite conversation."<ref>Bulfinch, Thomas. 1934. ''The Age of Fable, or Stories of Gods and Heroes'', p. vii. Biblo & Tannen Publishers.</ref>
Bulfinch originally published his work as three volumes: ''The Age of Fable, or Stories of Gods and Heroes'', published in 1855; ''The Age of Chivalry, or Legends of King Arthur'', published in 1858; and ''Legends of Charlemagne, or Romance of the Middle Ages,'' published in 1863. The original three volumes were later combined into a single volume titled ''Bulfinch's Mythology'', published in 1881.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=Sgg2AQAAIAAJ&q=bulfinch’s+mythology+by+thomas+bulfinch&dq=bulfinch’s+mythology+by+thomas+bulfinch&hl=en&ei=kRBfTcurA83qgQeX-NyJDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEgQ6AEwBjgo ''Guide to Reference Books'', 1929, page 89]</ref> Now in the [[public domain]], multiple editions of the combined work are still in print more than 150 years after the three books were published.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{gutenberg|no=4928|name=Bulfinch's Mythology}} * {{Google books|A6owAQAAMAAJ|The Age of Fable}}- a complete scan of the 1874 edition, browseable and downloadable. * [[Charles Mills Gayley]]'s book {{Google books|BbsXAAAAYAAJ|The Classic Myths in English Literature}}, which is ‘...based chiefly on [[Bullfinch's Mythology|Bulfinch's “Age of Fable”]] (1855)’ – a complete scan of a 1900 copy of the book, browseable and downloadable.
[[Category:References on Greek mythology]] [[Category:Mythology books]] [[Category:Books published posthumously]]
